The service was also unsatisfactory -- the waiter lead you to the seat in an impolite manner, and they only served you one basket of naans, no more. No inquiry about the order of a drink.

Besides these disappointing experiences, they charged more than the amount I paid with my credit card by $0.32 -- though not a big discrepancy, such dishonesty made me feel even worse about this restaurant.
author: Hazel H.

description: Really like this place.  the Samosas are excellent, the ambiance is great, especially when they play classical indian music. the coconut vegetable curry and baingan bartha are two of my favorite dishes.
author: Phyllis G.

description: The buffet is great.  I recommend it to my friends all the time. There is a good variety, friendly service and tasty food ( i am Indian and I cook Indian food well and I go to eat here on a regular basis).
author: Ruby K.

description:
What a disappointment! We'd been wanting to come here for ages!

We arrived at 6:50, gave our order to the waiter at 6:55 and then waited...and waited...and waited. The busboy brought out a pappadam with the mango chutney and raita we'd ordered to go with our meal. Then...nothing. The people at the next table came in at 7, ordered by 7:05 and their food was brought to them at 7:20. We hadn't even been brought our appetizer!? We finally asked where our food was as we HAD to leave by 7:35. The waiter was surprised we hadn't been served a-n-y-t-h-I-n-g yet and rushed off. He came back with our samosas which were so-so. We asked him to please bring ALL the food out, whereupon he ASKED US WHAT WE'D ORDERED!!?? He started trying to guess...and guessed WRONG! After half an hour of waiting, we had to repeat our order all over again!! Either he never wrote it down in the first place, or he lost it between our table and the kitchen!? It was apparent our order was never placed. By now we'd run out of town and had to get it to go! 

No effort was made to apologize or make it up to us in any way. Our mango chutney and raita was left on the table.
author: Carolyn D.

description:
Lunch buffet for $9.95

Lunch with my co-workers on a Monday, the place was not entirely empty but it wasn't full of people. The decor of the place was pretty nice and they fill up your Nan basket! Lots of selections and there's dessert too. 

I love their tandoori chicken. It had a deep smoky flavor that was moist and mouth-watering. Their chicken tikka marsala was creamy and spinach was bland. Their dessert consisted of rice pudding and fried cottage cheese balls dipped in flavored syrup. My co-worker thought it tasted like a honey dipped doughnut, the cottage cheese ball was hard and I personally didn't like it. 

I wouldn't come here again but if you like indian and want a good deal. Then the lunch buffet is your place.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Another great restaurant, 1 of 7 by this owner. Me and the wife  go there for their buffet lunch 4-times a week, Great Indian cusine,clean tables with tablecloths, great service, and a value for your money.
we also go there for dinner as  well, a great taste of india
author: Winston P.

description:
Indian food has to be one of my favorite comfort foods.  The Clay Oven (on Clement) is the perfect place for dinner on a cold night.  Ambiance wise, what I love most about the restaurant are the huge windows.  They make the place feel so big.

The food, itself, is amazing.  Can't go wrong with garlic naan and the vegetable korma!  I'm sure their meats are done well, too (but I'll leave that for my carnivorous friends to give a fair ruling on that). :)

For you vegetarians, I would highly recommend trying the vegetable korma & the Aloo Saag.

Lastly, they have also been known to give us free dessert (in form of tapioca in coconut milk with almonds)!
author: Theresa D.

description: Very disappointed. Ordered through grubhub - all three dishes were cold & the naan was rubbery. I had asked for cutlery as I have just moved into a new place, and they did not provide anything. Never ordering from here again.
author: Ketki K.

description: We were gonna go to our fave place in valencia st which was Maharaja but it closed down and since this is within walking distance from my house and the price is the same as Naan n Curry, I figured WHY THE HELL NOT! turned out to be amazing! To be honest, it did look a little intimidating because the decor inside was a bit fancy but once inside, you are greeted by polite staff and a good ambiance. Unlike other resto, this place didn't even smell like curry!!! The chicken Tikka Masala & Vindaloo was amazing. The garlic naan was to die for as its nice and fluffy and helluva big portion. Not to mention the crispy thing they give you as appetizers. Oh, we also got a free rice pudding! Definitly going back!
author: Angel U.

description:
Had a coworker who ordered food here.  I tagged on the order and tried the vegetable samosas...not bad.  They weren't too spicy, I was able to handle it, and I didn't specify spiciness when we ordered.

So the next week I ordered the pakora chicken, punjabi rice, and vegetable samosas...WAY TOO SPICY, even after I specified MILD.  Maybe I'm just a wuss when it comes to spicy foods.  I try, I honestly do...I like trying new foods...but this was way too inconsistent for me.  Two stars for delivering in a timely manner, but I'm probably not going to order from there again.  Especially not after reading that other review about the pubic hairs...

UGH...::retching noise::
author: Meesh K.

description: Still the best place I've been to for Chai Tea.  The buffet has somewhat dropped to average.  Still a good reason to go to the Outer Richmond.
author: Laurence H.

description:
i just have to review even after all these years!!! ive been M.I.A!!

ive come here a few years ago with my boyfriend for the first time and it was the most awkward experience ever.....!!! i was craving indian food and we came here since we were close by. went in and got seated. all 6 of the waiters, employees, cooks, whoever they were stood about 25 feet away with their arms crossing each other staring at us eating. we were the only people in there other than another couple sitting far far away from us. yes, its an indian restaurant. my boyfriend looks indian. BUT HE IS FIJIAN!!! (an islander-but he looks indian). the older guy came to take our order and we ordered some chicken dish and  the bf ordered lamb.. 

the chicken was really dry.. i didnt feel like eating it anymore, but i didnt want to be rude and not touch it.. since they would know.. we were being watched! i can tell they were being super awkward.. i dont know if i should say racist, maybe just being haters, but when the guy took our order, he asked my boyfriend if he wanted hot or mild..... then he asked me mild or regular?? what the heck was that about?! just yes, im asian, but i can eat spicy food!!! my bf told me theyre just mad because they think i stole one of their people.. HAHA!!
author: Jessica C.

description: Mmm...delicious Indian food!  Everything tastes so freshly made and I love their samosas, huge.  Quite classy atmosphere and enjoyed my dining experience.  Although I am a bit grossed out by Danilo A.'s review...ewww
author: Emy B.

description:
India Clay Oven has become my substitute for fine dining. 

The food is always good, the service is polite and efficient - if occasionally brusque - and there are ROSES on the tables. My husband and I are always hanging around drinking tea long after we're done eating, just because it's comfortable. How is that possible on a $35.00 tab?

I particularly love this place on foggy nights after a film at the 4Star. I was a cheap date, now I'm just cheap.
author: H G.

description:
reasons for 5 stars: 
LUNCH BUFFET! all you can eat for tasty goodness. extra fritters and all for the price of one plate 
amazing service. very attentive staff and accommodates your every needs 
the decor is really nice, tables are clean and the open skylight makes a difference 
a nice meal and ambiance for a great price. i will be back!
author: Katie C.

description:
ThIs is by far my favorite Indian restaurant in San Francisco, especially the Clement location. I always get the punjabi lamb curry extra spicy with rice! Yummy! 
If you have time during lunch, they have a great buffet!
author: SF S.

description: Ordered for delivery; pretty standard dishes, chicken Korma and lamb Biryani... This was a huge disappointment. Zero depth of flavor, the bland chicken cubes were floating in a watery half heatedly spiced sauce. The biryani came in a plastic clamshell way too big for it, smeared everywhere, and it was an odd reddish color, with a couple of sliced almonds on top. No spices other than a one-note heat, or herbs or raisins. The lamb was pure gristle. It was also expensive, especially considering the quality; the delivery was incredibly fast, though, and they were nice. I'll be ordering Great India from now on, I thought I'd try something different and it was a mistake.
author: Allie D.

description:
Granted this review is for the one thing we keep ordering from here. The Clay Oven Thali set menu is what we keep coming back for. Has everything we love to eat from this style of Indian food at a great price. In our neighborhood within walking distance and we come back every few weeks when we need a good dose of Tandoori Chicken, Boti Kabab, Saag Paneer, Papadam, Rice, Nan, Raita, Kheer, Veggie Samosa & Chicken Tikka Masala. The Bass ale on draft rounds out the whole meal and we leave extremely satisfied.

The staff is courteous and always wants to do a great job taking care of their customers.
author: Kira B.

description:
I've ordered delivery from here for about 2 years now... 

The quality is great - good flavorful Indian food without going overboard on the spices. 

Good quality and not greasy - always hot/warm on arrival.
Their garlic naan and rice are superb while the bbq chicken, tikka masala, lamb curry, and many other classic dishes all fit the rather bill very nicely! Hey
author: Roger C.

description:
indian food is always better in buffet form. especially if the dinner items can get a little pricey.  This way i can try about 15 different dishes for less than the price of a single dish on the menu.  Thus, you should come here for the $10 lunch buffet.  

my coworkers brought me here for my birthday lunch and it was delicious.  I was disappointed that I haven't been training my stomach with regular overindulging, so I was only able to force down two plates of food instead of the three I was hoping for.  Oh well, with fresh warm naan, and constantly refilled buffet dishes, I was in indian buffet heaven.  

I thought everything was very good, and they even labeled each tray with the dishes' ingredients, not just the indian names, for whiteys like me who always forget what's in each dish.

extra points for the white table cloths (though i have to think their laundry bill must be huge with people constantly spilling colorful food from their overflowing plates) and fresh roses on the tables.  Plus the waitstaff was impressive, refilling my water constantly (i'm quite the fish when i go out to restaurants).  if it weren't so out of the way, i'd definitely come here a lot more often for lunch.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: Came here with a friend for lunch because we were around the neighborhood and it looked really nice from the outside. This place is huge. The food was not bad but it wasn't anything to make a lasting impression. Very nice decor but poor service. Pretty cheap if you come for buffet. Ordering from the menu is not as worth it  though, and their portions are not that big.. Their tandoori chicken was one of the better tasting things in the buffet and their rice pudding was also pretty good.
author: Shelly M.

description: This is the BEST Indian food I've had; everything kids do good! The sag paneer is glorious, as are the chicken dishes. I live in the neighborhood, and I consider myself very lucky to live so close to such a wonderful restaurant. BTW, I just got back from the buffet: I don't usually like buffets (the mixing of different foods isn't good for my stomach), but I do make an exception for India Clay Oven!
author: John H.

description:
Just a quick note about this place. The food is incredible. BF and his boss took me here for my BD and it was so special.

Between 3 people we had Sag Paneer, Aloo Gobi, Onion Kulcha, Tandoori Prawns and Lamb Kabob served with Rice Pilaf and Raita. OMG soooo goood!!

The service is beautiful too. 

So I think this is our new special occasion place.
author: Sharon J.

description: It's been a while since my first review, and I have to say this place really grew on me. Their chicken tikka masala is a favorite, their naan is just right. Their lunch buffet is better than most.  I frequently had them deliver, they were always prompt and courteous. Dining room service is still very attentive, but I can't knock em too much for it. All around one of my favorite places for Indian.
author: Roger V.

description: Most pathetic food we ever ate...!!!! Please do not go to this place...even the service is not that good...all in all not recommended at all.
author: Ruchi G.

description: Love this place, you gotta try their Chicken Kofta Korma and Tandoori Chicken. better than any other Indian/pakistani restaurant that i have ever been to before..! Delivery guy Preet is awesome !!!
author: Anonymous T.

description:
Oh man, I haven't felt this satisfied in ages.  Ok, maybe last week when I had Indian at a downtown place, but either way I'm one satisfied puppy.

For some reason I've been on some Indian kick.  I was walking home from my workout class and thought "Ooo, Indian sounds super good right now."  I wanted to change it up and see if I could get a place to deliver that's not in the Sunset.  

I remember a couple years ago I ate at this place with a friend of mine.  I couldn't remember if I liked it or not, but thought I'd give it a shot to see if they'd deliver to my hood and wouldn't have a minimum of like $30 to get it to me.

I rang them up and the guy was nice.  All I ordered was some rice, chicken tikka masala and garlic naan.  Came out to about $20.  Sweet.  They said it would arrive 30-45 minutes.  Sweet.  

I took a shower, started washing some of my "delicates" and what do you know, I hear the door buzzing.  Wha, it's here already????  What do you know, it took them about 30 minutes!  Sweet sauce!!!!

As I opened my tikka masala, I drooled.  Super creamy sauce ... aww, perfect since I loooooove using naan to soup it up.  Come on, you know you do it too!  And you have to have the right thickness.  It had big pieces of chicken breast (why can't the Chinese places use real chicken breast?).  It looked awesome.  The rice was ok, it was just the basic stuff, but it was going to taste lovely with the tikka masala sauce.  Awwwwwwe yeah.  The garlic naan was pretty rockin' with the bits of garlic slathered on.

I think I inhaled the food, but oh it was satisfying when it was moving about on my taste buds.  I couldn't get enough of it.  I had to control myself not eat the whole thing because I want to have some for lunch tomorrow.

Seriously, this is now my go to Indian craving delivery place for my apartment.  It tastes great, fast delivery and reasonably priced.  All 3 things I want in a restaurant.

Now if you excuse me, I need to go put the leftovers away before I eat more.
author: imelda j.

description:
This is how i see it. If the kids from the neighborhood are calling this inner richmond gem "DELISH," then India Clay Oven is probably pretty damn good.

So we've been slaving away at work on a new business pitch, and a woman  who lives off Clement street decides to order our entire office food from Clay Oven. As she says "I KNOW good food. I live off Clement." Sure, whatever. I probably shouldn't second guess her instincts, because the food was tasty.

Got a taste of everything: the pilaf, the garlic and strawberry naan, two different curries, the tandoori chicken, the paneer and the samosas. You should try it too.

So go, eat, enjoy and prepare for a Indian food coma siesta.
author: Alex H.

description: tika Masala was watery as well as the curry chicken. The ambiance was nice the waiter was adequate. We regularly eat Indian food at least 2-3x per mo. This is a been there done that, dont want a t-shirt or to go again.
author: Brihan B.

description:
I usually don't like to sweat while eating - it isn't very sexy.

 I don't like to fan my mouth feriociously with my  hand while eating - it's not very classy.

I don't like to pant like a dog while gulping down cups and cups of water until the waiter brings the entire pitcher to the table - it isn't very elegant..

With that said, I hate Indian food. It's spicy. I do all of the above. Not very sexy.

However, after watching Slumdog Millionaire and being inspired by the bold, jewel-toned colors, humble people, beautiful art, and just the all around lively and rich culture -- I decided to open my mind (and mouth) to Indian food. I searched Yelp and found ICO.

ICO is very clean and elegant. A red rose in a simple, clear vase greets you at your table. There are tablecloths, beautiful white plates and shiny silverware. The menus are elegantly bound and engraved. Tall, cathedral ceilings make the dining area very open and warm.

The server is a beautiful, piece of Indian eye-candy. The busser was efficient and greeted us by bringing over two glasses of cold, ice water. I telepathically thank him -- because we both know, he'll be refilling my glass throughout the night.

We start off with garlic naan and Mango Lassis. Brilliant. 

Entrees - the chicken curry with a side of rice was good. It was on the small side, but it definitely fills you up. I had the chicken tandoori -  4 pieces of chicken [2 thigh and 2 breast pieces] marinated in yogurt, ginger and garlic, then roasted in their clay oven. It came out sizzilin' and piping hot.  It was spicy, but tasted very good. Their yogurt and spices combination was perfection. 

I love Indian food now, because of Indian Clay Oven. Thank you for opening up my eyes and mouth to such spicy goodness. Although I am in training, I will try my very best to conquer my fear of spiciness. Indian food, I will not run from you anymore.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
I am a huge fan of Indian cuisine and the fact that lamb is such a huge part of the culture, however this restaurant does not have good quality lamb. It is really chewy and tough, not really worth the 15 dollars per entree. The portions are decently sized, however the meat is too hard to chew through it easily. I'm guessing its not lamb, but mutton which is older than lamb. 

The chicken tikki masala is quite good, and their tikki masala sauce is tasty. But it's hard to go wrong with chicken tikki.

Decent restaurant but not really anything above a 3 star rating
author: Andrew O.

description:
In my opinion - simply the best indian food in San Francisco (Clement st. location) - the food is awesome! 
I'm taking 1 star off only because their stuff always try to seat us by the windows - sets me off on a sunny day. Also, some times it may take them a while to bring your order (given, they have not forgotten that you aksed them to bring a glass of soda). But other than that - great place with an amazing food.
author: Sing T.

description: What a neighborhood gem!  Hubbie and I always look forward to their chicken tikka masala and sag paneer- yum!
author: Lily W.

description:
I went here for dinner last night before going to see the last showing of Slumdog Mllionaire at the little theatre down the street. Things I absolutely loved about this place:

-The friendly, welcoming hosts
-The fact that there was a 20 person Indian family there for a birthday 
-The front wall is all windows
-The sassy but classy murals
-The delicious smells coming from the open kitchen (transparency = cleanliness)
-the huge selection of vegetarian options
-anchor steam on tap for 3.95. not bad!
-DELICIOUS paneer cheese with creamy tomato sauce and aloo saag and fresh crispy naan
-the 2 minute bollywood scene when they turned up the music really loudly for the little boy's birthday and the entire restaurant started dancing. wooohoo! 
-free gulab jamun from festive father of the birthday boy
-one of very few Indian restaurants in the Richmond

Things I did not like about this restaurant:
-the fact that it took 45 minutes for our food to come out
-our surly waiter (the only unfriendly person there)
-the fact that we asked for our check FOUR times explaining that we were trying to make it to a movie and we still just got up and paid on our way out because no one brought it. I also had to walk up to the kitchen to ask for a take away box because this request was also ignored. 

We thought an hour would be plenty of time for dinner but it clearly was not. Bottom line, don't go here if you are in a hurry. I will still be back because the food was delicious and lord knows nothing satisfies quite like a spicy curry. Mmm.
author: Rachael S.

description:
I was a guest for a special event that took place at India Clay oven.  On the surface it seemed like a good deal since our group (150 total) had a discounted rate and basically run of the whole place.   Food was setup buffet style with a choice of 6-7 dishes off of the regular menu.  Our group was large so waiting in line at the buffet was expected and since I was with a friend I didn't mind this at all.  Food overall was good.  I have had much better Indian food but at the same time I have had much worse.  The naan was dry and didn't seem to soak up the sauces too well -- but possibly it was the victim of buffet style Indian dining?

The wait staff here was extremely sneaky in my eyes.  They approached everyone in our party, offered a drink, brought the drink, and then demanded $2.  Feeling on the spot and not wanting to make a scene, I paid the $2.  The glass was mostly ice but I shrugged it off thinking that I'd make it up with refills.  HAH...when I asked for a refill I was promptly informed that there were no refills.  This alone turned me off most to India Clay Oven.  I don't like to spend money feeling that I am being jipped or being taken advantage of.  I walked out  of this restaurant with a bad taste in my mouth, and not from the food, and not wanting to ever return to this place.
author: Jonnathan C.

description: Best Indian food I have ever had! Excellent service and the staff is always wonderful. Not a bad thing on the menu. A few favorites are the Bangan Pakora, Mulligatawny Soup (big enough to share), Chicken Tikka Masala, Tandoori Chicken and the Saag Paneer. If you haven't been here you're missing out.
author: Tia A.

description: Really good cuisines for buffets! Excellent customer service and a great atmosphere overall!
author: Anhkhoa N.

description: This place is one of the best Indian restaurants in the city. Great food, great ambiance. Loved it.
author: Brendan V.

description: Food was delicious, super nice service, very courteous and attentive. Beautifully decorated room with great murals on the walls, warm ambiance. Very pleasant place for dinner.
author: Gennady B.

description:
This place has some delicious food. I love coming here. I don't eat a lot of meat, so this is a good fit for me. At other places, I struggle to find multiple things to eat, but it's not a problem here! I love the salad, rice w/peas, the carrots and peas, and the fried veggies. It's nice to have lots of light and windows in restaurants. 

The service is pretty good. The servers go around constantly making sure all the silverware, glasses and dishes are set out. Every once in a while, they come by with more naan and water. 

The downside is that the servers look tired/unhappy and don't seem approachable.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
Food: Fantastic!! I am a fan of their carrot pudding and kheer. Delicioussssssss! Nice hot naan too. 

Service: Exceptional! The servers were friendly and nice, one explained to me what all the dips went with as i stared and poked at them. 

Setting: SunnyLarge Windows and Tablecloth seating makes it one of my favorite weekend brunch places now. Its so naturally "outside" inside. 

I had a wonderful experience here! Definitely looking forward to returning!
author: Amy S.

description:
My brother comes through town every so often with his family in tow and with a specific food preference. This time it was for Indian food (he's lived in Bangladesh a couple of times). Since there are two Indian places within 4 blocks of my house, I recommended the better of the two. 

India Clay Oven is foremost a nice dining experience. The dining area and restaurant is quite elegant: pretty decor, nice table settings, and a wall of windows in the front with good lighting. Dinner becomes more elevated when you have such a nice ambiance. And yet not such an elegant situation that my young niece and nephew couldn't be themselves. And all this ambiance isn't actually costing much more than the competition nearby which isn't nearly as nice.

The food is quite good. I've eaten here a number of times and a few times had food delivered. Their Naan selection is particularly good and delicious. We had Garlic Naan, Spinach Naan and Potato stuffed Naan. We liked our Fish Tandoori and my brother said his Lamb Kabob was especially tender and tasty, too. I like the Chicken Tikka Masala, but then for some reason this dish seems well prepared almost everywhere I go. My other brother had a yummy looking chicken soup. I liked that they had an iced chai available, too. 

At the end they comped us a couple of dessert rice puddings and I made the mistake of not tasting it until just as we were leaving (we were so full!)...it was delicious and I almost asked to take it to go (but this would've been kind of silly and a lot of extra work and packaging for a little bowl of rice). Next time I'm eating my rice dessert!
author: Liza B.

description:
Not your classic variety of Indian cuisine. More of an exotic and lighter blend of curry, jasmine rice, and naan is very yummy. Upon request only. 

My sister and I also realized that there is a "secret menu", so you need to go to the website before you visit this restaurant to know what is offered there.
author: Bianca L.

description:
We go here quite often-- the food is good, service is always phenomenal, and it's in the neighborhood.  They also deliver though I still have not taken advantage. 

I don't think I've had anything here that I didn't like.  Favorites for us are the Chicken do Piaza, Alloo Gobi (Cauliflower and Potato), Bengan Bhartha (Eggplant), as well as the Chicken Tikka Masala.   I should try some more stuff on the menu but we always tend to order the same things every time we go.  I also like their Chai Tea.  Did I mention they usually give us complimentary rice pudding at the end of our meal?  

Very nice decor with cloth tablecloths and napkins, and fresh flowers.  And like I said, the service is great.  Not sure if I would go out of my way to go here since there is so much great Indian food around town, but worth a visit if you live in the neighborhood.  They also have 5 other sister locations in SF.
author: Yvette H.

description: I love this place!  Great atmosphere & service.  Very accommodating and adaptable to you liking.  I had lamb coconut curry and asked that they add red curry... Fantastic; the lamb had no tenants and melted in my mouth.  Me love had a prawn curry and they were perfectly cooked.  Most definitely going back again:)
author: Olafur G.

description: Last time I order from here after six years of delivery.  Food quality has gone down, portions have shrunk and prices soared.  We intended to stop ordering several years ago, but lacked alternatives.  Price value relationship is poor at best, food is not great and tonight they blatantly lied about delivery - I was told five minutes more, then 45 minutes later, five minutes more.  Never again.
author: jeff w.

description: At first this place was good but their quality starts getting bad once you frequent it often. After I kept feeling like death everytime I was eating their food, I eventually stopped ordering from Clay Oven.
author: Darius A.

description:
My Indian food expectations have risen, and this place meets my new standard.  My chicken tandoori was tender and moist.  The sautéed onions were plentiful and actually done to perfection, not served almost raw.

The floors have no traction.  They are not carpeted.  I did not slide, but I had to think about walking which is something i typically like to do without thinking.  The tables are very close to one another.

The service is slow.  Very slow.  There was a 20 minute wait for the bill before we stood up to go find the waiter and ask for our bill.
author: Brooke R.

description: This is the best Indian restaurant in San Francisco.  The food is incredible and they are so nice!  We arrived at 10:30 on a Saturday night and they gave us five-star service.  Truly my favorite Indian restaurant in San Francisco.  You can not go wrong here.  The Chicken Tikka Masala is fantastic!!
author: K K.

description:
Omg, this place is fantastic.  For $50 you can get a whole meal suited for about 3 people (even though it says it's for 2), and that includes tandoori chicken, boti kebab (lamb), rice, naan, samosas, and dessert.

The food is excellent but a bit on the pricey side, since the dishes don't come with rice or nan, so you have to order them separately.  I highly, highly recommend the kashmiri naan to eat plain, since it was sweet and stuffed with cherries.  It's almost like eating sweet bread for dessert.  Their mango lassi is AMAZING - much more mango-y than Avatars, my former go-to place for Indian food.

Overall, excellent.  Good service, great selection, fantastic food.
author: Tori S.

description: Me and my honey tried their lunch buffet twice in 3 years, and got food poisoning both times. Too bad, we live in the neighborhood & love Indian food, but this place is simply dangerous. These days we just go a couple of blocks over to an Indian restaurant on Geary near 24th Ave. A bit pricier, but worth its price in Peptobismol.
author: Sandra B.

description:
I really enjoyed this place.  I've had Indian food all over SF and the east bay, but this place is one I would return to. Although I didn't have the leftovers, I am sure they were great. 

I had the fish Tandoori and the presentation was nice, but the fish was buried under the cabbage, which spoiled the first impression view. Feel free to say I'm being a little picky there.

The only problem I had was the too attentive wait staff. They do circle around enough to keep the water glasses filled, but I really don't like to be asked 3 times if I need anything else, 3 times I'm done and 3 times if I want dessert. Its as if they have no idea they are interrupting our conversation.

The flip side to that was, when we were so slow to leave they brought us chai tea without asking us and at no charge.  That more than made up for the pestering.
author: Mac S.

description:
I was a first-timer and went to the buffet this past weekend. YUM! 
Staff was friendly and generous, always suggesting items for me to try.
My only gripe is the 2.00 sodas and no free refills (I didn't know this until I got me bill- D'oh!)

Try the chicken masala tikki something or other. The naan is free and so yummy!
author: Amy B.

description:
wow!  Excellent service!  The food is quite good!  Been a fan since they were a tiny little joint. Then, one day, when we went there, I was hella sad that they were gone....then, oh hey, look!  They moved across the street to this phat spot with huge windows!  Quality is same as ever!  Chicken tikka masala....my favorite!  Naan, good!  Very fresh!  Warm and chewy!  Saag paneer, good!  Curry salmon, good!

see you soon, india clay oven!
author: Peter M.

description:
I've never been to enough Indian restaurants to know what is authentic. So in this case, I just have to say, I enjoyed my dining experience here. I had the buffet lunch, while my wifey and mom ordered off the menu to take advantage of an Entertainment coupon. This is a very pleasant restaurant with skylight windows and murals of Indian scenery and artsy caricatures. If you're a fiend for white table cloths, they got 'em. Full bar... sweet. The servers are friendly, and the service is good. The guy who might be the manager, visits the tables to check on you. Very cool.

Indian curry has a much different flavor than Chinese or even Burmese. Much more kick, and you have the option of how much heat you want on each dish. The lamb is pretty lean, so the flavor isn't as strong as usual. The Tandoori Chicken is roasted with spices, flavorful, but a little dry. It may be better when cooked to order. The creamed spinach type dish is really good, and they have a garbanzo bean dish that's cooked in a very spicy hot tomato sauce that's extremely awesome. I like to put that and some spinach on the garlic naan bread... aw, man! And the naan is served warm, and you do get a variety of seasons to choose from, like garlic. There's also a dish of lamb with flavored rice and nuts that great too.

OK, the prices are moderate and portions are generous. Parking on Clement Street is... well, it's better than east of Park Presidio. I'll be going back a lot. Check it out!
author: Rick V.

description:
I agree with Zelda M., the service can occasionally be on the slower side. Lately, it's been good and we are served relatively quickly.  It all depends on who's working that evening-  there's a huge turnover and some servers are better than others. Lately, one of our favorite waiters has consistently waited on us, with back up.
 I find the food to be very tasty and freshly made.  We ask for it mild and get it that way. 
The Mulligatawny Soup is excellent. We used to get it with every meal but found it didn't leave much room for the delicious entrees, Now we do an either/or thing. The naan is usually good and fresh  but has been disappointing at times and didn't seem to be baked long enough. 
When the restaurant is full, it can be noisy, but it's rarely full. It used to be packed when it was across the street and you had to wait to get in, but then, it was much smaller. The new building is a little too cavernous for my taste. I find the murals that adorn the walls all around both beautiful and intriguing.
author: Jack S.

description:
Every long established tribe of friends has their own set of archetypal characters. We're no exception. There's free legal advice guy, bro-who-will-bang-girl-you're-interested-in-when-you're-not-looking guy, the drunk groper, thinks-nobody-knows-he's-coked-up guy and me: orders-for-everyone-at-ethnic-estaurants guy.

I've accepted this role with enthusiasm, especially since it's been able to help me retract from the most loathed of group roles: figure -out-the-bill guy.

So last night I was late and the tribe had to figure it out themselves. They did all right. *

Even though I didn't order it, the food was really good.

* Note to Free-Legal-Advice Guy: Two platters of that sizzling tandoori chicken that no one really wants....Really? Hey, guy don't go chasing waterfalls, PLEASE stick to the rivers and the lakes that you're used to.
author: Jason R.

description:
If any restaurant owner would bother inquiring as to what would make my dining experience most enjoyable, I would have to tell them, "offer a buffet or combination plates."  I'm one of those people who always has a hard time deciding what to order, and it always makes my night when I can sample multiple items for the price of one entree.  

I believe I sampled about 6 dishes at India Clay Oven's buffet, and for $9.95, that's a pretty good deal. My favorite dish was the lamb curry, but the chicken tikka masala, tandoori chicken, and vegetable curry were all tasty.  My boyfriend loved the chana masala and saag paneer (spinach/cheese curry)--but aesthetically that particular dish is just unappealing to me (it basically looks like a pile of green diaper poo) so i didn't give it a fair shot.  The only let down of the entire meal, was the chai tea which tasted weird and the naan bread, which tasted quite Americanized.

India Clay Oven has a wide selection of buffet dishes, everything was hot and pretty fresh (i.e. I didn't get the feeling it had been sitting out all day), and all of the curries I tried were pretty solid, with plenty of spice and chunks of meat.   The buffet's only available for lunch, so you should definitely go then instead of dinner.  But be prepared for the post-Indian buffet food coma.  I was full and sleepy for the rest of the day.
author: LaSha G.

description:
YUM! I heart indian food!

I came to this place with my bf for a quick bite on a sunday afternoon, and we left full and satisfied! For $9.95 you can't go wrong with the buffet. All the items were tasty and they kept replenishing it! Best part was they bring the naan out to you fresh, so its always piping hot :) My favs of course is the chicken tikka masala, paneer, and the lamb curry! 

My only disappointment was that we didn't realize that validated parking lot is only in the evening, and not for the lunch. No worries, it didn't ruin our lunch.

I've also come here for dinner before and the food is also delicious, but a lot more pricey than other indian places.
author: Betty S.

description:
Lunch Buffet =)

I love coming here on sunny SF days, even on cold days the sun streaming through the windows is perfect! 

If you don't feel like making choices, this is your place. Just try a little of everything! Plenty about the food in other reviews. FYI the Na'an comes to your table after you've dished up your first helpings. NOTHING in the buffet is spicy, so for you mild eating friends, have no fear ;)

Delish!
author: Angel L.

description:
I always enjoy having dinner here. It has such an elegant atmosphere, yet it's laid back and friendly at the same time. And, of course, being in the neighborhood is a big plus.

I've come here a number of times and seating is always immediate. You absolutely never have to wait for a table. Most of the time I consider that a bad sign for a restaurant, but I actually love this place.

Malai Kofta is my favorite thing to get here. It's true that some of the items on the menu here are nothing special. They're still okay, just not phenomenal. Malai Kofta has never let me down, though. Yum!

Food usually comes out quickly, especially when you're busily munching on delicious dips with papadum while you wait. Mmm.... Sometimes they're a bit slow to bring the check at the end, but you just need to get their attention and ask for it.
author: Megan Y.

description: I hate to write a bad review because the workers were really nice. I order chicken tikka masala and it was so watery it was basically water.
author: Amanda C.

description:
First, I have to qualify my experience here. My wife and our friend had just snuck in 18 holes at Lincoln Park, and by "snuck" I mean that we played the 18th in the dark. Seriously, we were aiming at a light on the clubhouse. How we even found our golf balls along the way I will never know. Long story slightly longer... It was foggy, windy, cold, and we were starving. After a conference in the parking lot, we decided to hit Clay Oven. 

When we got there, there was only one other table occupied (plenty of people came and went for takeout, though). Needless to say, prompt and attentive service was not a problem. My beer arrived quickly, as all beer should. Our order was taken and the Papadams and Vegetable Pakora hit our table within a few minutes. Now, it may have been the freezing round of golf skewing my taste buds, but the dips and the apps tasted fantastic. 

On to the main courses: Chicken Tikka Masala, Mushroom Masala, and Aloo Matter (all medium spicy). Even though we were there late, we were unrushed. The entrees came out a few minutes after we were done with the appetizers. Presentation was very nice and the flavor of the dishes was super. The mushrooms especially. Good amount of spice, not overpowering, so the complexity of my Aloo came through. It was slightly annoying that the waiter came by quite often to ask if everything tasted OK... but by that time we had the place to ourselves, so I can excuse the undivided attention. 

Service was great. Everyone there was incredibly friendly even though I am sure we were keeping some of them from heading home. Very reasonable on the wallet, everything tasted great. Oh, and the restroom was immaculate. I don't normally point something like that out, but it was exceptionally clean. So, if you ever decide to freeze your ass off for the privilege of chasing a ball all over the damn place... why you'd want to, I have no idea... I mean, it sounded like it would be fun and we did meet a really cute Boxer puppy so that upped the fun factor somewhat... um, anyhow, you could do worse than making Clay Oven your 19th hole.
author: Don B.

description:
After living on chicken tikka masala sandwiches in the 6 days I was in London, all I've craved lately is chicken tikka masala on naan w/ raita. After attempting to recreate my UK experience at some mediocre places, I ordered delivery from this place after seeing it get a favorable review from my girl Megan W. (that bitch knows her Indian food, okay?). 

It was so delicious! The raita (which really makes the meal for me because I am a yoghurt freak) was creamy & sour & a perfect complement for the spicy chicken tikka masala. It's a little pricier than other Indian delivery places but you get a ton of food & it is soooo worth it. So, the moral of the story is: listen to Miss Megan. She knows her shit!

I've had several wonderful delivery experiences from India Clay Oven but the food here is very, very heavy. For a lighter meal, opt for Great India right up the street on Geary (or have them deliver to your house). However, for creamy CTM, this joint rules.  And you can order online, via delivery.com
author: Maria D.

description:
My night at India Clay Oven....

Super Bowl sunday around 8pm....My roomie and i were literally the only two customers, which was nice in a way....1 star

There was some sort of car accident outside, and we were placed by the window so we were provided with entertainment....1 star

The food was decent and prompt.....1 star

The waiters who weren't waiting on us were obviously bored, so they kept pacing around our table which got annoying and weird. Like seriously, you guys don't have a break room??....minus 1 star

A weird drunk guy kept passing by the window staring at my roomie and I and making googly eyes at us. After the third pass by, he comes into the restaurant and says something to the host, walks to our table and says, "Can I join you, ladies", as he reeks of alcohol. As this inappropriateness is going on, all of the waiters, male waiters, just stand and watch as this old ass drunk, tries to creep on us.....minus 2 stars for not having our back and letting the guy, who was, again, not sober and obviously not our friend, come to our table and interrupt our dinner.

The guy who came and towed the car that was outside was wayyyyyyy hot.....1 star
author: Kayla T.

description: Avoid at all costs. This restaurant should be shut down. Ordered special dinner for 2. Initial plates delivered to the table had food from previous use still on rims. Waited 30 minutes for second course which was hot plate of over cooked lamb and chicken backs. Waited again for condiments and rice. The busboy wet mopped the floor repeatedly around us while we waited for our dinner. Chicken masala finally arrived raw in the middle of each cube. We asked for bill and left.
author: K J.

description:
I got a few standbys: chicken tikka masala, bengan bartha and plain naan to soak it all up. It's a simple series of dishes, but you know when you have a bad one, or even a so-so one. For me, the problem with Indian food in a lot of local places is the fast-food element. Food is quick, reasonably tasty and cheap, with an environment to match. That's great for lunch, but less good for dinner and chatting, which is what I was looking for this time around.

India Clay Oven scored a lot of points last night. Food, artfully prepared, is in small, round, classic-looking serving dishes. It felt like they really took their time, adding just the right amount of every ingredient. Not cheap, but not ridiculous by any means.

The place itself is high-ceilinged with beautiful artwork on the walls and tons of windows. Candles that double as dish-heaters once the yummies come out of the kitchen are on every table. The service isn't bad, but the last couple times, they seemed bummed we showed up and started ordering things.

In a 'hood with restaurants galore, I think I found my go-to Indian spot.
author: Tara R.

description:
A minimalist review:
India Clay Oven is half a block from my apartment.  They are reasonably priced and produce a quality chicken Tika Masala.  Yes, they have peas in their basmati rice; but, they conveniently pile them at the top of the rice carton so you can scrape them into the garbage if you do not like peas (such as is the case with your's truly.)  The people who work there are nice and they also deliver.  Their dining room looks warm, friendly and exceptionally classy as compared to most Indian restaurants I've been to.

Snap.
author: Kate R.

description:
This is a very attractive restaurant that serves great food and the service has always been great each time I've gone for dinner. It's also been great for something as easy as a take-out. The interior is nicely decorated and has gorgeous high ceilings. Their food can prepared as spicy as you'd like but beware, I once got a sore throat from the spices being so hot! No joke.

It may be a little far out in the Richmond for some people but you'll get over it once you've tasted their food. Look out for coupons/specials, they come in handy as the menu could be considered somewhat pricey as others have mentioned. Great for a date or a group of friends.
author: Gabriel R.

description:
Just the way I like it! I love the food here. The ambiance is nice, and so is the service. You also can't go wrong with the cute server that helped us too. I don't kow if he was into me, or he was working his tip. Either way, you got it. Thank you Clay Oven.
But I will add on, I recently ordered take out and it wasn't as good as dining it, kind of flavorless. It still doesnt ruin my opinion on this place
author: Miss P.

description:
The service here was very attentive.
Chicken Tikka Marsala was wonderful. Had some nice heat to it. Chicken was a bit overdone. 
Great for large groups plus free validated parking.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I hadn't had Indian food in a while and India Clay Oven delivers so I figured why not. They botched up the appetizer, though and instead of palak pakora (spinach coated in garbanzo batter) I ended up opening a container of cheese pakora (I think...) They tasted like fried dough. 

The assorted bread basket was decent and consisted of garlic naan, Kashmiri naan and chapati. The Kasmiri naan was stuffed supposed to be stuffed with nuts, raisins, coconut, and cherries though I could only detect cherries and coconut. The sauce in the lamb tikka masala was spicy and great with garlic naan. The lamb was tough and chewy. Eh, you win some, you lose some.

The standout of the meal was the gulab jamun, brown cottage balls fried and soaked in a flavored syrup. Very sweet and dense and only a few bites will do ya. Don't want to fall into a sugar coma. 

All in all, I don't know if I'd order again from India Clay Oven. Perhaps I'll just stop by, though I hear the waiters aren't exactly of the friendly, chipper kind.
author: Nathalie L.

description:
This place has pissed me off each of the 2 times I ate there.  It has great ambiance, so i went twice...but the waiters are rude, they rip you off every chance they get (they ask if each persaon wants rice, then bring a ridiculously large bowl of rice for each person, then charge for each bowl- they do the same thing with the naan, and with everything else).
The food is so-so, but pretty greasy, and WAY overpriced.

Go to great india instead.
author: Ali M.

description:
India Clay Oven's lunch buffet? IT'S OOOOOOOOOVER! 

(make sure you fast for at least a day before visiting this place)

Great location, food and ambiance. If you get a window seat, take a look at the place right across the street. That's where their old restaurant used to be. An upgrade, no?

The Indian beer is dope too. (don't mix with the buffet at the risk of losing the ability to breathe, followed by your stomach exploding)
author: Vince M.

description: Food is great, atmosphere is great, location, a bit far. But well worth the drive. Love the Chicken Makhni, and the chai tea is phenom. Wish parking was better and more crowded. I don't relish fighting crowds, but it feels a bit isolated.
author: Susie D.

description:
Monday night found me way out in Starla's hood for some indian food with her and A.K. It's tough to park out here and the locals drive like they're really pissed off because they can't find parking. You should take muni or walk or something.

The building is kind of unusual, but bright and nicely decorated. The service was fast, but it wasn't particularly busy. If you order a glass of Kingfisher they'll serve it in a Stella goblet. These are all useful details.

Everything will taste good if you're starving; It's only good food that will make you want more even when you're not all that hungry. The entrees here passed muster in that regard, though honestly I can't say I was floored by any one thing we ate. Starla thought the chicken was a little dry, though what I had tasted fine; Either she just picked an uncommonly dry piece somehow or her chicken standards are higher than mine, probably a little of both. And Pakora is much better when it hasn't been sitting under a buffet heat lamp for 45 minutes, as it turns out. I'd also order the Sag Paneer again, and the yogurt sauce we put on everything if I could remember what dish it came with. There was something else but I can't recall what it was; It was probably decent though.

I have a container of leftovers in my refrigerator which I probably should have offered to Starla or A.K. to take home. I am inconsiderate and thoughtless sometimes; This is also useful to know. If my dinner plans don't work out tonight I'll be able to update this review later on.
author: matthew r.

description:
I've had better (and for cheaper). There are definitely a lot better Indian restaurants in the city. It's just that this one happens to be really clean and fancier looking than your usual hole in the wall Indian restaurant. 

I came here on a weeknight, so it wasn't busy at all. There was probably one other table that night. The service was good, our waters were refilled regularly. This place is a little more expensive than other Indian places, but that's probably because it's not as dingy (about $10 per dish compared to $6-$7). 

I ordered my usual, bengan bhartha (eggplant), along with a few naans and a side order of rice. I wasn't impressed with any of these dishes. I still ate it, but it's definitely not something I'd ever come back for. I'd rather drive to my usual spot in the TL and be surrounded by crackheads.
author: Maryann T.

description:
After being discouraged by the line at Pho Garden (since when is there a line at Pho Garden?!?!) and checking out 2 Japanese places that were closed around lunch time, my friend I stumbled down Clement until we crossed paths with India Clay Oven. I remember hearing (and smelling) good things from my old roommate when it came to this place, so we decided it couldn't hurt to check things out. 

We walked in and were sat at a table near the windows that were open. The sun was shining in and the breeze made the room smell so fresh. After we got some water, the waiter insisted we go for the buffet and who were we to disagree? We grabbed some plates and chowed down. 

I have to admit- Indian food is a new venture for me. I've only eaten it in the past 2 years, and even then it's been sparingly. It's weird because I every time I eat it, I think "man, I really should eat this more often, it's so good!" yet I never crave it when I'm hungry. Well my thoughts after this meal were no exception. Although I left fuller than I was hoping to feel, the food was really good. My initial fear of mass-produced food for a buffet subsided after I started eating some of the chicken, lamb and veggie dishes. All were amazing! There wasn't a thing I didn't try that I didn't go back for seconds. 

The place has a huge back room that looks perfect for banquets or large parties... so if you need a dinner locale for your next Bar Mitzvah, the Indian Clay Oven will make your non-pork eating dreams come true.
author: Jared S.

description:
9:45 PM on a Thursday and hunger comes a creepin' like a malnourished Mexican street dog begging at my table -  I have no choice but to oblige.  Given I live four blocks from this place, I called them up.  They were more than happy to deliver, even given the time (and my extreme laziness), and they pointed me to their website to check out their menu.  I found what I wanted, one of their meal deal dinners, and not too long later, all sorts of Indian goodness arrives, nicely packed, at my door.

Excellent chicken tikka masala, nan, sauces, etc.  A LOT of food for the price.  Two entrees, loads of rice, salad, chai, rice desert pudding thingy, lentil soup.  Mmm mmm good.  I'm still looking forward to the leftovers.  Super nice on the phone, and also excellent when my ladyfriend and I went to dine in.

All around great service, excellent food, and most certainly my go to spot for the late night grub necessities.  Good date spot too, should you actually choose to put some pants on and go outside.
author: Quinn Z.

description:
Someone else suggested that you should fast for a day before hitting up the lunch buffet. Fair enough. But really, you should be more prepared for what's going to happen *after* lunch -- you're going to fall asleep for three hours, and you're not going to need any dinner at all.

I've been coming back to this place over and over for years. I admit I've gotten some funky-flavored lamb dishes, and occasionally bitten into something that wasn't quite the best part of the chicken. But on the whole, I've found few Indian places around that are peers of the ICO. Reasonably priced dishes, decent enough atmosphere, tasty food (both veggie and meat).

By the way, the back room of this place has the nicest bar in the neighborhood, though there's almost never anyone back there. Big-screen plasma TV, little booths, nice liquor cabinets, marble bar. If I were Robin Williams and I were looking for an after-dinner drink somewhere I wouldn't be noticed, I'd slip out around the corner to the ICO.
author: Paul B.

description: Nice place, good food. Music was a little too loud, we had to speak over each other. I also wish that waiters would wear cleaner shirts and aprons. I understand they are in and out of the kitchen all day but still when you bring food to the table and your white sleeves look like a mix of salads its a turn off.
author: Ger L.

description:
Food here is good but better than the service.
Decor - 4 Stars, fairly nice
Food - 4 Stars - Vindaloo and Tikka Masala both good (a bit too creamy)
Naan - 3 Stars - good but nothing special
Service - 2 Stars - upsell pressure, avoidance, and unlabeled bill

I would come here again to see what it's like on a different night. The food here is better than Great India but also more expensive, so you get what you pay for. Slightly better than Maharani  but not as good as Shalimar, Chutney or Guddu de Karahi. I would say it is definitely worth checking out, but I would probably go with ordering delivery than eating there.
author: Sven S.

description: I wouldn't say that this is the worst or best place I have been to. Its decent. Had the luncheon buffet which is nice because you can try out all the different dishes. What I didn't like is that they had just finished cleaning and the entire place smells like pine sol. Also, they sat us down (party of 6) at a table, its 11 am and the tablecloth is dirty, then we moved to a second table, still a dirty tablecloth, then finally a third. The table cloth is not a fresh one, but it's doable. I guess they like to reuse the tablecloth until it's really dirty....
author: Jay S.

description:
The only other times I've been served papadum was as an appetizer, half starved and willing to eat anything.  ANYTHING.  Which may explain why I was unimpressed with this flat, crisp, delicately spiced savory wonder.  Well, wouldn't you feel the same way if you were expecting hearty curry and naan and the first thing they brought you was an Indian version of tortilla chips?

We ordered take-away and everyone put in their 2 cents on what the British really eat when they have Indian cuisine.  Lamb was voted twice and we ended up with the lamb curry which was good.  The chicken jar-freizie was DELICIOUS.  There is something truely magical and heartwarming when you put spices together with fresh diced tomatoes.  The flavors come together like iron filings drawn to a magnet and in the same way, makes visible the electromagnetic lines that run beautifully proportioned patterns.  

Lastly, I wanted something I'd had at other Indian restaurants known as dal saag.  At this locations it's known as palak dal.  Spinach with lentils.  Good and hearty, not too creamy.  Saffron rice anyone?  Yes?  BF's mumma desires it?  Of course.
  
An order of regular naan, 1 cheese naan, and 3 orders of kashmiri naan rounded off the order.  And 6 papadums.  

Wait around for 10 mins before getting in the car and heading in to the outer Sunset district.  Well, I didn't go, but my BF relayed how harrowing the experience was because he couldn't turn left on 25th ave and had to drive through the park.  

The naans were the diameter of basket balls.  I loved it.  The papadum was so good that I had dreams about eating when I woke up the next morning.  They were even good as a snack mid-afternoon, and when I thought no one was looking.

Chicken jarfrezie: the sauce made me think about that time, you know, any time when things were wonderous and everything felt alive.  It was so new and yet so comforting that I must have known it in another life.

Lamb Curry: I ate it for breakfast, in the shame of the corner of the kitchen, hidden away from all the other sensible adults who had things like granola, fresh fruit and yogurt.  I ate the leftover sauce and enjoyed the sensation of tingly indian spices flowing down my throat.

Palak dal: decent.  Not as good as the other place that calls it dal saag but hey, it was tasty enough for me to have two servings spread on toasted naan, the day after and I still wanted more!  I think it's just something I'm going to have to get over.  Like herpes.  Just KIDDING!

Papadum was fantastic.  I could finally taste all the exquisite complexities that go in to the very flat and crisp disc.  I've developed a fondness for it that resembles my fondness for dental floss.  And believe me, I have a curious attraction to dental floss.

Saffron Rice: it was so popular, there was none left over.  

Never have I had Indian take-away so the experience was compared to in-house "formal" dining.  And what I have to say is that we may never eat AT an Indian restaurant again when such good take away is possible.  Just call, place your order and then send off my BF to pick it up.  It's as easy as delivery and he even plates it for me.  What a doll.
author: Christina C.

description:
India Clay Oven serves some of the best Indian food around!!!  When I tried Indian food for the first time 13 years ago, it was here.  While I have gone to many other Indian restaurants in SF and other cities too, nothing compares to India Clay Oven.

When we first visited the restaurant back in the day, we discovered that our waiter was the owner himself.  We asked for everything mild.  Over the years when we dined in and ordered delivery, he slowly turned up the spicy volume on all our dishes.  Needless to say he has been very good to us!!

Our favorite appetizer is the vegetable samosa - fried and shaped like a conehead -- huge!   The soup to try is the Mulligatawny.  Our breads would either be Nan or Onion Kulcha.   The dishes of choice are Hydrabadi Chicken, Chicken Tikka Masala, Kashmiri Kabob, Saag Paneer, Mattar Paneer and Prawn Tandoori.  For dessert, we order the Kheer (rice pudding) or Gulab Jamun (small ball of cake doughnut rolled in sugar and served in a light syrup).  Drinks are the Masala Tea (similar to chai) and Mango Lassi.

Their all-you-can-eat buffet is a favorite in the neighborhood.  It's usually crowded on weekends, as it is a pretty good deal.  In my book, India Clay Oven is worth 6 stars.
author: Janet H.

description:
Monday night, football on TV. .. laziness in full swing. I'm ordering delivery food! 

* indulge * 

To my dismay, my favorite Indian place (Shalimar on Polk) doesn't deliver. FML. My second favorite place (Tikka Masala on Ellis) doesn't deliver to my area... (Presidio)... double FML. 

I found this place on line.. they were one of the few willing to deliver to the Presidio. 

I'm such a slave to my laziness, I am willing to pony up the $13 for each entree... yes.. EACH... entree. I'm thinking this Indian food has GOT TO BE GOOD if they charge that many rupees. 

1 lamb curry, 1 chicken tikka, 1 spinach, 3 naan, 2 rice: $52 

Food was delivered in a timely fashion. 

Food was warm. 

Sauces were thick and sticky... not creamy like usual. 

Chicken was tough and dry (even though it was immersed in the tikka sauce). 

The spicy lamb curry dish was delicious... not quite $13 delicious.. but.. tasty. 

I learned my lesson.. next time I'm lazy and craving Indian food... get my ass off the couch and order take out from Shalimar. I can spend the money I save on a tasty bottle of wine (the same amount of food at Shalimar costs $28 and tastes 5x better).
author: Kaitlyn G.

description:
It's been freezing and I needed a pause from my dat tour, so what could be better than delivery? Didn't know that this place is related to all the other Indian delivery places. I actually thought I was trying to find the better one! Anyway, it took about an hour to deliver, but I wasn't starving so it's ok. The tikka masala was good, slightly better than average. The naan was ok, but I liked the plain better than the stuffed ones. Also got a shrimp dish, forgot what it's called. Could of used a few more of the suckers, we got mostly the sauce. 

ICO was good and the fact that I'm lazy and they deliver means I'll get it again at some point.
author: The Sock S.

description: Tried the lunch buffet on a whim.  We had lunch the previous day at Hard Knox next door, and thought we should come back and try India Clay Oven.  It was very good and a great value for $9.95 a person.  A nice variety of dishes; fish, lamb, chicken, vegetarian, all very good.  Will definitely go again.
author: Janet S.

description:
Boycotted because they threw plates on me and my date four years ago when we showed up to eat too late. I had been coming here for 10+ years, and was quite dismayed at the horrible rude service. 

Indeed.

But the food was always delicious.  Perhaps I'll let bye gones be bye gones someday and update my review, but for now I'm sticking to the lovely place on geary and 25th.
author: Kristi D.

description:
So, I usually only go to Indian restuarants when they offer their rockin' all-you-can-eat buffet lunches which cost less that $10. Tonight was different.

I went with two girlfriend post-workout, and I didn't feel a slight bit embarassed by my appearance/outfit. 

We ordered some sort of set-menu, that looked sorta like this:
Clay Oven Dinner
For Three  
Comes with:
Chicken Tikka Masala, Boti Kabab, Tandoori Chicken, Vegetable Samosa, Vegetable of the Day, Papadam, Rice, Nan, Raita, Kheer.

The highlights, the bbq-ish sauce that comes with the papadam, the tiki masala sauce, and the beef kabab. The other stuff was O.K. Sorta wished we got regular naan, instead of the fancy garlic and onion one. I was the only one into the rice pudding for dessert.

Anyway, stuffed my face, and there were leftovers. 

For just over $20/person, I'd rather return for the buffet.
author: Misha F.

description:
The 4 star rating is due almost exclusively to the tandoori chicken.  It is well-spiced, moist, and tender.   I had lunch here with an Indian friend, and he was impressed by this dish, and the restaurant in general.  Other items in the buffet to note:  lamb curry (very good), chicken tika masala ( very good), chickpea dish (sorry forgot the real name - NOT GOOD), naan (very good, nice amount of clarified butter).  

I like the new, lighter, brighter location, but I kind of miss the quirkiness of the old place, which granted was a little tattered, but had more of a homey feeling.  

The service, while not fast, is always delivered with a huge and genuine smile.  

Oveall tasty & satifying, like a perfect mango lassi.
author: Liz S.

description:
The food was pretty decent but the portions were (I kid you not), tiny dishes of everything. I think I could have gulped one dish down. 

I've never thought of Indian Food being posh, so when the bill came out to over $125.00 for 5 small dishes, I was slightly taken aback. If the portions were a little bigger, I don't mind paying more but it was the size of a kid's plate and it was a dinner menu too, not lunch. 

I might try their lunchtime buffet next time...
author: Mashimaro M.

description:
A damn great place.  We went there for Father's Day because my dad wanted Indian food.  I was in a bad mood because I got the wrong instructions on which avenue it was on and ended up hauling some packages down three blocks before I found it.

The decor was beautiful and majestic.  I thought... this can't be an all you can eat Indian buffet place.  It isn't a hole in a wall.  Then I saw my family waving at me, so I was relieved.

http://indiaclayoven.ypguides.net/

The food was wonderful.  So wonderful in fact that I forgot about blowing my top and screaming at them for picking a restaurant that was in the land of no parking and then giving me the wrong address.

The food wasn't mounds and mounds of brown stuff that tasted OK, the food definitely had zing to it.  The Nan was tasty--freshly baked.  My sister asked for it without butter and got it.

I'm not sure of all that I ate, but I couldn't get enough of the lamb or the yogurt.  My husband thought it was just OK because everything wasn't cold or hot.  He thought the fish and vegetable pakoras were a little dry.  

I think he was the only one that thought it was just "OK."  My dad, mom, two sisters, and I adored the place.  

This is the place I would want to come to for my 42nd birthday.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
I hate this place and won't ever eat there again...

As I recall, the food was decent.  I just didn't like the management.  At the time I went to try it, I had an Entertainment coupon for buy one entree, get the second half price or something like that.  OK, so you understand that the commitment was to purchase two dishes, right?  Then you would get the benefit of the coupon for the second, right? 

Well, I not only ordered two dishes, I ordered maybe 3 or 4.  The manager then tries to get me to order a vegetable dish, (which was the cheapest) so that he could give as little of a discount as possible!  What a jerk.

Like I said, the food was probably pretty good (though I wouldn't rave about it or say it was exceptional for Indian food...), but there are other places just as good or better to give my business to.
author: Leslie W.

description:
Yeah baby! And I haven't even tried ordering á la carte yet, but solely based on their Naan and Chai I believe India Clay Oven is as good as it gets. Nowhere in town have I tasted such wonderful Naan; light with a perfect touch of crispness and flavor. Try the garlic and/or potato Naan, and I'll look forward to your nods of approval. Also, the Chai beats much other Chai I've tried. Naan & Curry go home.

The interieure has a wonderfully luxurious feel to it with lots of wood, and the white table cloths, nice silverware, and fresh roses on the tables don't hurt either. The floor-to-ceiling glass walls that face the street keep the dining room bright, and underscores the cleanliness of the place. It's a place fit for the royal treatment, and we were indeed treated royally when we showed up casually for a Saturday lunch.

The line of steaming silver bowls abundantly tempting our appetite was impressive. All the dishes were labeled, and the staff otherwise attentative to answer any questions we might have. Why even bother look at the menu when the buffet was right there crying for us to jump in?Of course I had to go back for seconds of the tandoori chicken, the ginger chutney, and dessert. And I'll keep coming back without much interest in exploring Indian food elsewhere- at least for a while ;-) At the end of the day, it's hard to beat great food and service with a smile.
author: Kirsten L.

description: We stopped here last night as we were on leftover turkey burnout and needed something that was nowhere near cranberry sauce, mashed potatoes or stuffing!  We went a little overboard and ordered three appetizers (samosas, pakora and aloo tikki - the pakora was my particular favorite) then for our entrees we ordered chicken tikka masala, punjabi chicken curry and spicy chicken makhini, as well as some saag paneer and rice.  Driving that savory smelling stuff home without attacking the bag was a special challenge!     And I'm here to tell you that when you order spicy chicken makhini, baby you get SPICY chicken makhini!  Good stuff!  We were also given free Chai while we waited for our to-go order- a very nice gesture and a perfect warmup drink on a cold November day.  We'll be back soon for our next India Clay Oven fix!
author: Cindy D.

description:
The food was passable. Service was a bit rushed and very forgetful of our requests or boxes to go. 

The dinner for two featured a tandoori chcken and tikka masala, which were both very good, but portions were small for a 20 per person meal. 

If I shared it with my girlfriend it would be perfect but for two guys it was just a tad too little.
author: Stephen D.

description:
I'd rather pay for what you can eat than give the all you can eat lunch another try.  Layaly across the street was closed, so a friend and I decided to give India Clay Oven a shot.  Service was a little awkward at first; we didn't know about the buffet, but the waiter thought we did.  So we had a few moments staring at each other with confused looks until somebody came over to clarify things.  No harm done.

There were a few dishes that I was familiar with, tandoori chicken, curry lamb, and a few things that weren't so familiar, including a deep fried vegetable dish that was probably the best dish there.  Unfortunately, most of the dishes were bland and lacking the spicy hot fare that I'm accustomed to.  And I really had to dig around in the chicken tikka masala to really find any good pieces.  And like many of the reviewers here point out, the naan here is a little moist.

The friend I came with assured me that he's had better for dinner here before.  So maybe I'll come back for that.  But as a lunch option, I recommend going elsewhere.
author: Tony L.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in my neighborhood. I've never had bad food from here and would highly suggest the chicken tikka masala and spinach naan. 

The staff are awesome also, usually always the same guys working. They've also been very kind and helpful.
author: Julie T.

description:
I'm starting to really love Clement between 25th and 26th. I've been to Hard Knox and now India Clay Oven, and we still have to try the Mediterranean place, the Japanese, the Thai, and the Taiwanese place.

India Clay Oven was great. Friendly staff, clean, warm atmosphere, awesome bathrooms, and tasty food. Reasonable prices, too.

We had chicken tikka masala and bangan bharta. We sopped our dishes up with plain naan, which was slightly chewyer than I prefer, but still tasted excellent.

The vegetable samosas were served hot, and were standard fare, but standard samosas are delicious. We had the option of dipping them in spicy green, spicy brown, marmalade-ish, or yogurt dill sauce. I tried all and can't pick a favorite.

The prices are a little steep. We left paying a little more than $50 for two people, so don't look for a bargain. Just solid Indian food.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Thanks to Junie for picking this place! Eugy and I were going to go to Naan-N-Curry since it's cheap, but Junie suggested that we all go here. We were not disappointed. 

This is a white table cloth dining establishment. Pretty big inside and very clean. And the mural on the wall is beautiful. But don't let the white table cloths fool you. This place is VERY reasonably priced. 

We ordered:

Chili Naan
Garlic Naan - YUMMMMM
Dal Soup - Not what I was expecting. It was ok, but I like lentil soup to have whole lentils in it. This was ground into pulp. 
Krahi Gosht - Lamb in garlic. This was good and the lamb was SUPER tender and not too gamey. Junie and Eugy wanted it to be more gamey, but I liked it the way it was. 
Chicken Tikka Masala - I always order this when I go to eat Indian food. It's always a safe choice. At this place, it was REALLY REALLY good. 
Prawn do piaza - This one was another big favorite of this meal. 
Bhindi Masala - That was the first time I ate okra since I was like 4 or 5 years old. And it just reconfirmed the fact that I hate okra. Won't be eating it again. 

Overall, GREAT meal. Definitely coming back to this place!
author: Jen D.

description:
Tandoori Murghi.  Tandoori Chicken to those of you who do not dine with Jason Bourne.

Chicken cooked well with a very tasty yogurt sauce.  Tasty like bathe in it tasty.  Naan and rice and I am getting aroused again.

Fish and shrimp are dicey options unless you remove them from the scalding hot skillet first.  Missed that bus and incinerated my shrimp.  I ate my companion's instead because I know Jason Bourne.
author: Jon K.

description:
I just got married and my Indian wedding was one of those huge, four day events. Part of the planning was caterer tastings....and so, I think I'm in a good place to judge Indian food.

I think this place is great. I was pleasantly surprised by how tasty the food was. At most Indian restaurants, I'm bracing for mediocre food that's cooked so fast the flavor just sits on top of the food instead in the food. Not India Clay Oven! The food had flavor and texture and it wasn't overpowered by just the spices. 

It's not ultra-luxurious or fancifully creative, but they're not trying to be that either. It's solid north Indian food that served in a casual-elegant setting. The dining room is all windows and it really adds to the whole experience. 

Two thumbs up!
author: Palak S.

description:
Very nice Indian restaurant. The dining room is beautiful, which was kind of weird since I was dining with a guy friend!

The prices were pretty reasonable, and the food was delicious. I had chicken curry and spinach with rice and nan. It could have been spicier for being the medium heat...I also tried my friend's which was supposed to be hot, and yes, it was hot, but not hot enough where I couldn't handle it, and that's not saying much.

I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Stu M.

description:
$9.95 all you can eat lunch, that's GREAT. We came in after the rush I guess since they were still cleaning some tables. So they sat us and told us we could go to the buffet to get what we wanted. They were all nice and accommodating. Since it was pretty slow we had very attentive waiters. 

There was a great selection of food at the buffet. I'm not sure if it changes ever so often but it was pretty good anyway. They also had two desserts, one was Kheer, which was like a rice pudding and the other I can't find on the take out menu, but was a bit more heavy and made with carrots and chickpeas. I did like the rice pudding, light and not too sweet. 

Atmosphere was great since they have nice big windows and music was at a decent level, could still talk to people in a normal indoor voice.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
This is a very nice restaurant. The space and decor are not the typical Indian restaurant style, it is a very pleasant place to be.
The service is always excellent and be sure that if you ask the staff to make your food spicy it will be just that....I have joked that the waiters take side bets about customers' ability to handle the heat.
I have tried many of the menu items and have never been disappointed. Always tasty and fresh and well presented, though I recommend a hearty appetite before ordering.
The lunch buffet is very good value but the dinner prices can add up once nan and rice etc. has been added. It is worth it and in my opinion this is the best Indian restaurant I have eaten in in California.
author: Mark T.

description:
Can I speak to the authenticity of any of these dishes? No.
Can I remember the names of these dishes or tell them apart? No.
Do I like Indian food in buffet-quantities for under $9? You bet!

The fourth star is for ambience...the front of the restaurant has a cool aquarium...atrium (aquatrium?) feel to it, surrounded as it is by tall windows.

The elusive fifth star would be awarded on the day they offer curried chicken on naan submarine-sandwich bread through a to-go window.
author: Enrico L.

description:
This place has the best Indian food I have had in the city!!  The real deal. The Samosas were amazing!! I loved the atmosphere of the restaurant. All of the waiters were really nice and helpful!  They boxed up our food and even gave us extra yummy sauce to go. On top of that they brought us free rice pudding! Soooo good! (It might've been due to a miscommunication, but nonetheless it was rad). Definitely going back...and hopefully soon! By the way, get the Kingfisher beer they have on tap, it's REALLY good!! 
We even had the pleasure of seeing a bride, her groom, her priest and guests enjoying the experience too. First time for everything!
author: Sonya D.

description:
Being deathly tired of Thai/Chinese/Pizza takeout, my friends and I decided to order from here a few weeks ago.  We got Chicken Vindaloo (hot), Saag Paneer, Rice, and Garlic Naan. It was all super good, and the Chicken Vindaloo was blisteringly hot, just like it should be. 

Since the food was so good the first time, I decided to order again a few days ago, but I was with people who don't like having their taste buds singed off (their words, not mine), so I stupidly ordered a milder Chicken Vindaloo.  While the hot one was thick and had a nice texture to it, it seems as if they filled 1/2 of the container with the hot vindaloo, and the rest with water.  The Vindaloo was so thin it was almost transparent, which of course is very far from ideal.  

I don't know if I just got a bad vindaloo batch, or if they actually do just dilute the real stuff (anyone else experience this?), but yea, if you're getting food from here, definately DON'T go with mild stuff that should be hot.
