On another note, the Saag Paneer is awesome. that is all.
author: Eric W.

description: Good lamb with garlic sauce.  However, the garlic naan was over-cooked, dry, and oily.  Mediocre sweet lassi.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Delicious chicken tikka masala. The lamb, however, was really greasy and in my opinion inedible (although my dining companions didn't seem to care). My one problem is that unless you go out of your way to ask for your food medium or hot, it comes really really mild. 

Service is attentive, but really slow to bring the bill. You should probably ask for it about 15 minutes before you actually want to pay it.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
For the lunch buffet, the price couldn't have been better.. I've been stuck in a rut and usually food does me good, so I decided to head out and try this place out. I've heard some really good reviews of this joint, so I had to see what all the fuss was about. 
DUDE for $30 dollars for TWO people with drinks and all you can eat Indian food! THIS PLACE ROCKS!! 
The fact that their food is actually fresh tasting, and the naan is brought out so fresh that you can hear them pounding the dough is awesome!!!
I will def come back to enjoy some really good Indian buffet!!
author: Eric A.

description:
Their atmosphere is great compared to most Indian restaurants in the area (Raja tries...but fails in this respect I think), and their food is delicious.  

Their goat cheese naan is good, 'naan' of that regular stuff...ok, that wasn't funny, but I always like to work in a naan joke if I can.  I love their veggie dishes and the tiki masala wasn't too heavy with the cream (a lot of places do this, see rotee).

I think I came here for Valentine's Day this year...and it was a perfect place :-)  Everyone I know who has been here loves it.
author: Kristin E.

description:
I honestly have to say I will never eat here again and will not recommend people to come here. 

This is buffet style Indian restaurant.  Maybe because I really do not like Indian food but I basically hated every dish there except for the naan.  To me, almost all the selection of food look the same.  All very stewy and has a really strong taste. There wasn't a big selection of food either. I really felt like I wasted my $20.  

As side from the food and price.... the interior is pretty nice.  The capsule they used to put the food in was really cute and the staff was nice.
author: Jannifer H.

description:
Having gone to the Yelp Holiday Party last night, I woke up in need of something delicious and comforting - and heavy enough to soak up the alcohol still lingering in my stomach.

This place is awesome for its lunch time all you can eat buffet alone. (I think its 1130-3ish?) You get all you can eat for $7.95. Now, I can't eat that much, but I make an honest effort when I come here simply based on principle. 

The dinning room is beautiful, which almost doesn't match the restaurant in terms of cost - but it makes me feel classy, even when I crawl in there with a mean hangover, still wearing the clothes I slept in. 

Very satisfying!
author: Crystal A.

description:
Indian food isn't my favorite, but I enjoyed my dining experience at India Clay Oven.  I've never been to a classier Indian restaurant (except maybe Dosa in this Mission).  I like the subtle details the restaurant had to offer: white table cloths, festive dishes and serving pots (albeit a little cheesy), and the overall dimmed lighting.  

The food was very tasty.  We ordered the onion fritter which wasn't what I expected, and wish they offered a better dipping sauce for it (we ended up using the comp sauces the provide for the flat crispy bread).  Aside from that the mulligatawny soup was divine and might have been my favorite part of the meal.  I dipped my garlic naan in it.  We also ordered one of the chicken kabobs and a potato and pea stew (which was also great with my naan) and both had great flavor.  

Staff is attentive and helpful.

I will definitely go back to India Clay Oven as I had an overall pleasant dining experience and there's so much more to try and experience.
author: Marie B.

description:
There's really not many places in the City where you can get incredibly delicious food, all-you-can eat, for just $7.95. 

I ate here recently at 11am, for their all-you-can eat lunch special and was stuffed well into the next day. Wonderful food, plenty of variety, great service and completely inexpensive. 

The restaurant itself is beautiful, with huge windows overlooking Clement St. In the back there's a nice bar with a large Plasma that looks like a great place to have a casual drink.
author: Justin B.

description: We had a great meal here! Really delicious goat-cheese stuffed naan and baingan bharta. I love the interior of this restaurant too--it's relaxing and elegant. We had great service too. No complaints. This is great Indian!
author: Elina R.

description:
Two times I've ordered delivery and two times they've magnificently botched the order. (both times being no less than 30 minutes after their stated delivery time)

since they botched the order so bad the first time my wife attempted to check before the delivery guy left. He refused to wait. Complained about the amount of the tip. (seriously. to her face).

the food is pretty good, but definitely not special enough to compensate for service issues.
author: James F.

description:
I am afraid that this place has changed how I feel about Indian food;
Its not as unsatisfactory as I have thought for years and years now.

The lamb curry was very good and the bread is tasty as well.
Excellent price, very very clean, and did I mention its a buffet?
author: Anton M.

description:
This place is literally the only spot in San Francisco that makes spicy Indian food spicy.  Make sure you get something to chill your pallet, you'll need it. 

If you like tikka masala, this is the place.
author: John V.

description:
I know Naan & Curry is overrated and all, but compared to this place, it is still better.. 
The variety is very small (about 1 chicken, 1 lamb, 1 beef, some random stuff and vegetables) and the price is not that low.
I expect them to ATLEAST provide free refills but NO, they charged me for each time they filled my glass..so I ended up paying close to $8 for cokes?? wth.

Yeah, go somewhere else.
author: Catalina C.

description:
I came here for the lunch buffet. The food was slightly above average. Now I'm not saying its not good mind you but its not something you'd write home about. 

Main dishes: 3 to 3.5 stars

Wiith that being said I have to say their naan is FANTASTIC. it has a crispy outer layer with a doughy, chewy center. Their naan alone is worth going back for. My only wish was that I had known how great the naan was going to be and I didn't fill up on the rice. 

Naan: 4.5 to 5 stars
author: Alex P.

description:
From this day forward all the other Indian food I've had is hot garbage compared to India Clay Oven. 

I came here with my besties on a Friday night. We used open table for a reservation, but when we got there we realized we didn't really need it. The place was busy, but we didn't have to wait and there were a few empty tables. 

The servers were on thier game, but if you have a sensitive tongue as I do, I would recommend getting a pitcher of water so you don't have to flag them down every five minutes.

We split the Clay Oven Thali Dinner for 2, which was more than enough food for three straving marvins. I would recommend this location for groups, dates, and last meals.
author: Madalyn F.

description: Buffet was quick and easy. Not the best food ever but not the worst either. If a quick lunch is needed this is alright.
author: Brian J.

description:
$9 for a lunch buffet aint bad at all. I was about to walk out cause they had no Chicken Tikka Masalla. Dude was all hyped up about this other dish I had never had and said it tasted just like it. This dish was called Makhni. Hella, hella, good is what it was. Service was perfect too. 

I had Basmati rice, Some kinda fried fish, Cucumber salad was hella good and refreshing!!! I had all kinds of crap that was good. The good thing about the buffet is that it let me taste more dishes I normally wouldnt have.

This was the first time I came in as a paying customer. I installed the telephone system here a few years ago and also ran into Norman the manager. Good seeing you again Norman!

Afterwards, I went and walked it off at the end of Clement is Lands End Trail! View of the Pacific Ocean and GG Bridge!!!
author: Marlon O.

description:
YUM!

We've come here several times and always enjoy! The wait staff is very friendly and attentive, you always get seated straight away (even in large parties!) and the food is always piping hot and delicious. Very reasonable prices too!

We always order the Chicken Tikka Marsala, rice and a couple orders of Naan. So, so delicious! One day we will have to branch out a bit more and try some other menu items... We just love the Tikka Marsala so much that it's hard to stray from it.

One star taken away simply because I have not eaten at enough Indian Restaurants in the city to feel comfortable calling this place 'the best'. I will confidently say however that it is very GOOD and the service, compared to other restaurants of any ethnicity, is well above average. We had gone about 3 times... on the 4th visit one of the waiters recognized my boyfriend and noticed his recent haircut! *WOW!*
author: Tamara B.

description:
My absolute favorite place for lunch on the weekend.  All you can eat lunch buffet for only $7.95.  On my plate you'll find rice pilaf, fried fish, spinach with cheese cubes, and the chicken makahni.  Oh my.  Nan comes with the meal.  I've often joked that I would like to bring a large tupperware bowl and just fill it up with the chicken and that creamy, spicy yogurt sauce.  Other favorites include braised lamb, tandoori chicken, and a variety of vegetarian dishes.  Dessert must be the Kheer - delicate, yet delightfully cold, this is made of basmati rice cooked in sugar and milk, with almonds. 

Get your fix of several of this restaurant's more popular dishes during lunch.  Don't bother going there for dinner.  Dishes are extremely overpriced and small portioned.  The chicken makahni alone costs $11 on the dinner menu.  Need I say more?

Don't expect friendly service.  Most likely you'll be waved to an empty table and get an annoyed look from your waiter if you don't order something to drink aside from water.  Our running joke is how fast they can give you the bill before you're finished eating.

They have a sister location on Folsom called India Garden.  Same MO on the buffet layout.  Service is friendlier, but the food at the Clement location is a bit better and cooked with a little more care.
author: Denise M.

description: Best Indian Buffet in the Richmond.  Delicious and a very clean and nice atmosphere.  You even get free Naan with the buffet!
author: Andrew Christian C.

description: Food was pretty good - had mixed grill, some lamb stuffed naan (which was quite tasty), and a mixture of other things. At the end of the meal, they brought my son free gulab jamun, and followed it up with free mango ice cream for him. Nice touch!
author: Jane J.

description: I've have Indian food on a weekly basis and this is by far one of the best!! The food, the service and the ambiance are great! If you haven't been here, you are missing out
author: Mayya S.

description:
This is a little restaurant in the middle of Clement Street.  I went in for dinner and had a nice window seat at the very front.  Since it's summer, the light was still out, and in the sunroom, the room was very bright. 

Chicken Tikka Masala is really good here, probably the best I've had.  It was creamy and spicy and went so well with the naan.  They give you a little cracker appetizer with chutney sauces before dinner, which was good enough for me, because I almost tried to finish my order, but alas, I had to finally declare my tummy happy and call it a night.
author: Lorraine D.

description: The food was 80% good and reasonably priced for the lunch buffet, overall.  I did experience concern for the hygiene however, as more than one employee had noticeable body odor.
author: Devin V.

description: We order from India Clay Oven probably once every two weeks in the hope that it wil be good.  It is inconsistant.  When it is good, its really good, when it is not - it is discouraging.  Stagflation has also hit ICO - and I noticed last night they cut our nan into quarters as to make us feel like we were getting the same amount that we normally do - however it was significantly less.  I am sad to say that I will need to find another indian restaurant that will deliver to my hood - as ICO has let me down for the last time.
author: Jenn D.

description: Came here a few times for their lunch buffet.  Loved it!  And for $10 a person... it is a GREAT deal.  I enjoyed everything in the buffet.  The chicken marsala, the saag paneer, rice pilaf, potatoes, fresh salad, fried fish and vegetable was all very good, tasty.  And the naan was delicious!  It is served hot and was chewy.  There is also dessert--rice pudding and a carrot pistachio dessert.  I liked the flavor of the rice pudding, the consistency was a bit runny for my taste, but I enjoyed it all the same.  All in all, a great place for Indian food, especially if you want to try a little bit of everything...all the more popular Indian dishes.
author: Kailee Q.

description: This place started off excellently. What happened is I seen one waiter disappear, and so did the quality control. I went alone as I was driving by, the place looks great inside, like a wedding banquet or something. What I had over and over again was great, that was the lamb vindaloo, and the chicken tandoori. Well, to my disappointment the lamb quality went down when the waiter left the restaurant. Any way the chicken should be great with the rice and naan bread. Otherwise great possibly for weddings.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Came here for dinner... Service was just okay. Food was  on the rich side (but what can you expect when you go indian?)  and a little pricey for ethnic foods. They had great lassies and that makes me happy! 

This is like a great date place for dinner. candles. table-cloth.. etc
author: Helen H.

description:
blech!

In deciding between one or two stars, my fiance urged me to go for two stars because "it's not filthy or anything."  

We've had some good meals in the past, and last night we headed here because we wanted some Indian food in a restaurant that was a bit more formal than a hole in the wall.  We really should've gone to a hole in the wall.  The papadam we ordeded was stale and chewy; when I asked for fresher papadam, we got a new batch of stale papadam.  The food we ordered was so-so; I liked the lamb korma, but the goa shrimp was bland and the saag paneer was salty.  Also, if you go, order it hot; medium was weak!  

Finally, the waiter tried to insist on rice, we declined, they brought some to our table, we refused it, and they put it on the bill!  I'm so sick of that move!
author: Pamela D.

description: I love Indian food, and this is one of my favorite places for it in the city.  The staff is also super friendly. I have always gotten great food here.
author: Cathy R.

description:
Get the lamb korma no raisins. Just do it.

Everything else is pretty good. Service is slooooooooow during dinner but I'll deal because they're just that good. Everything I've tried here is pretty good but I usually order the exact same thing for dinner everytime:

-Chicken tikka Masala(chicken is overdone but who eats tikka masalla for the protein anyway? the sauce here is the best I've tasted. )
-Lamb Korma no raisins (really tender cubes of lamb in an amazing creamy curry sauce with bits of nuts)
-Saag Paneer(this is the only place I'll order this dish. Every other place I've tried it comes out really funky. Like bad funky.)
-rice to eat with the saag
-a couple orders of naan

I suggest you bring a couple of friends, but I've gone with just one other and finished the meal. I'm not saying it was the smartest thing to do and we could barely waddle home but it was totally worth it. This place is pretty expensive for an Indian joint but you get what you pay for. Don't get me wrong, I love me some Naan 'n curry, but once in a while I crave an actual legit Indian meal and as far as I'm concerned this is the only place to get it.
author: Nadia P.

description:
Despite the fact that I'm a white girl from Alaska, I absolutely adore Indian food! Give me a tandori, vindaloo, some naan and a chai tea and I'll be happy all night. So imagine my diappointment when I was unsatisfied with my chicken korma. It was bland and the chicken was dry and the sauce was watery.  Now normally I could eat chicken korma for breakfast, lunch and dinner. But I'm sad to report that more of mine when untouch. It was a good thing that I enjoyed the other items that we ordered. 

The lamb vindaloo, garlic naan and the vegetable pakoras we ordered were all up to standard. The lamb vindaloo was the perfect amount of spicy and the meat was tender. The parkoras were crispy and not too greasy. 

I will say that I liked the decor and feel of the restaurant, we were seated at a nice table by the indow.  I might try it again for thier buffet lunch just because it had a nice environment. I'd want to be able to try lots of items next time though, since the Korma was so disappointing.
author: Marissa P.

description: Nice decorations with indian music playing in the background while eating. The service was quick and attentive. The food was delicious. I tried the chicken korma. They gave us free complimentary appetizers. Additionally, I tired the mango lassi and it was delicious. I recommend this place for good indian food.
author: Jason L.

description: Walked in to a Beautiful setting. Elegant paintings on the walls and lots of windows for a sunny lunch. Waiters are so friendly! Very nice service, a very welcoming place. Food was  delicious, It was my first time eating Indian food there. Spice filled chicken, great flavor inthe lamb. The naan is sooo good! We had the lunch buffet , 9.99 a person. This restaurant is So worth the momney. We had about two plates of naan, a soft flaky bread that we decided to dip into their chicken and lamb sauces. So good. Love this place. Definitely coming again!
author: michelle w.

description: Romantic - single rose at each table, large windows to stare at the night sky, and lovely candlelit scene. Sweet staff and delicious food. Naan was good
author: Jan S.

description: My search for the best Indian in town brought me here. The restaurant itself is nice, good service. My food review is based on the lunch buffet which was tasty. The usual fare typical of buffets done well. The Nan was hot and fresh. No samosas though. Boo hoo.
author: Lauren N.

description:
OK guys.

So the food here is solid.  Like 3 stars kinda place.  Buffet-quality, but consistent, good selection, you know what you're going to get.

They get special kudos for the layout and the staff.  I mean, it's a fancy-ass sit down place for an Indian buffet in the city.  Have you seen some of the other places?  It's a place where you could take that out of town friend and not feel bad because it looks like a dump.  Staff is great - helpful, friendly, nice to have around.

Nice place to have a group gig as well (roomy area in the back).

Good stuff, for sure!
author: Linda C.

description: I am surprised this place doesn't have higher reviews! I'm always surprised also that there are not more people eating here. They have such great service and really quality food. They are quick, polite, and I know the food will always be good. They have a couple good beers if you want as well. I don't know if they always do complimentary rice pudding, but it's definitely a nice touch for my wife and I when they leave it at the table. Highly recommend this undiscovered treasure!
author: Joshua J.

description: Very consistently good lunch buffet, quick service, and the BEST flippin' naan I have ever had. Very simple. There is not much else that can be said about this place, other than it is a gem.
author: Thomas E.

description:
I really really really love Indian food. And I really really really hate service with attitude. So, this leaves me at 3 stars with India Clay Oven. The food is yummy, but prepared to be bullied by the waitstaff (no, we don't want 4 separate orders of naan and 4 more orders of rice for the 4 people at our table). Stopped going after we discovered Great India on Geary @ 25th. The food is better, cheaper, and they're not jerks.

UPDATE - 3/31/08: There's a new chef at Great India and the last meal we ordered was terrible. Bummer.
author: guinevere h.

description: Incredible. Chicken Tikka Masala was amazing. Perfectedly accented with Rice Pilaf traditional Naan and the Tamarind and mint sauces. Really good stuff.
author: Mark F.

description:
I'm usually not a big fan of Indian food, perhaps because of the many bad experiences I've had in the past.  My wife and I decided to give this place a shot this past Friday night and I am very glad we did.

The place was packed, always a good sign, yet we were still seated right away and a great table for two by the window.  The staff was very attentive (we were helped at various times by THREE different people) and they brought out our appetizers very quickly.  We ordered the Palak Pakoras, which is Spinach coated in garbanzo batter, then deep fried.   They are mildly spicey, but a nice surprise (I ordered them on a whim).  We also ordered the garlic Nan, leavened bread coated in garlic.  It was great!  For dinner I had the Chicken Makahni (Tandoori chicken cooked in a mildy spicy sauce) and my wife ordered the Lamb Coconut (Lamb simmered in coconut milk).  Both were delicious and was enough to share (we aren't BIG eaters) and bring home for lunch the next day.  The price was reasonable and they deliver!  If you like Indian food, give them a shot!
author: Jason d.

description: My favorite SF Indian restaurant.  Parking for dinner can be a problem; but lunch parking is usually available.  I normally go there for the lunch buffet - the tandoori chicken and naan are incredible; topped off with salad & rice - great!
author: Brian C.

description:
My husband and I went to India Clay Oven today for lunch.  Luckily, they have an all-you-can- eat lunch buffet from 11:30-2:30 for $10.00 per person.

I've honestly only tried Indian food about three times in my life, so I went without really knowing what to expect.  India Clay Oven has received high reviews on Yelp and my neighbors have told me to try it - so I didn't think I'd be disappointed.  

I wasn't - the food was fantastic, the service was great.  My water glass never got half full before it was refilled, and our dirty plates were immediately taken off the table.

I loved the mango juice, the marsaro chicken, Punjabi Spicy Curry Chicken, and the veggie dishes.  Their rice pudding was also very good. My favorite was the fresh-baked naan, which they brought to our table still piping hot.

Overall a very clean, very reasonable and very delicious restaurant.  I will certainly be back, and I recommend that others in the area try it as well.
author: Jennifer U.

description:
I went back for dinner tonight, and it was very delightful. This time to avoid the cost of alcohol, we brought our own beer, and they were completely fine with it! Major plus.

I ordered the vegetarian Paneer dish, and it was very good. The spices were perfect. My friend ordered the Punjabi Spicy Curry Chicken. It wasn't very spicy, but still very tasty. The only thing wrong with it was that the chicken was a bit on the dry side.

The staff, as always, were kind and attentive. After our meal, they gave us a complimentary dessert. How nice of them! Went home  with leftovers that will serve as a nice snack for later.

Definitely going to eat there again. I want to try one  of their spicier dishes.

Also, I just heard that they have a great all you can eat lunch buffet for only 9$, if you're in to buffets.
author: Chelsea H.

description:
I needed a quickie lunch today while doing laundry and was craving a burger, but with only 20 mins to eat, decided Bill's was too risky and hit up the buffet at India Clay.  

The chicken masala was splendid, however everything else offered was mediocre.  I'd especially have to single out the lamb curry and vegetable dishes, which had a little flavor and belong more in a chunky soup can.  For dinner it might be better - it's a cool space with a nice bar in the back.  

Overall, I left a little disappointed, although it wasn't horrible and I didn't get sick.  But, for a buck less, you can get a better lunch at Great India, which is just a couple blocks away.
author: John H.

description:
Hurrah! Tandoori goodness only 1 1/2 blocks away! If you're like me (i.e. broke as a joke), the sight of swanky digs can be a little depressing. Luckily, Clay Oven only looks like an ultra pricey restaurant, and in reality, is super reasonable. 

I had the tandoori chicken and naan bread. The chicken was sizzling hot, juicy, and way awesome. The naan bread was fresh and good. 

The only weird thing is how close you're seated to other patrons. I apologize to the middle-aged squares sitting next to us. You know a lot about my sex life now. Sorry.
author: Nikki H.

description:
The food is alright, nothing special, it will sit very heavily on a stomach full of beer, just like a good curry should.

The big drawback is the service, which is very pushy. You are constantly being harassed into ordering more food. Most of this pushiness is direct, some is not.

Examples include questions like "What kind of naan bread would you like with that". A question which leads the Clay Oven novice to assume naan is included. It is not. Also the tables already have a plate of pickles and dips on them. You are asked if you would like some popadums to go with the dips, but you are not told that they are a buck each. Imagine going to a Mexican restaurant, sitting down to a table with three types of salsa on it and then being charged for chips.

As for the music. Gah. I could be eating food cooked by the Lord himself but if I have to listen to KKSF-style "smooth jazz" while I'm eating it, well, the whole experience is ruined. Especially if the Lord keeps coming over and shaking my still-full beer bottle to see if I want more. And for the fifth time Lord, no, I do not want any dessert. Or any more rice.
 
If you want a decent curry at a better price with better service and no shit music, try Raja on the corner of Haight and Fillmore.  Stumbling distance from the Mad Dog as well.
author: bristol b.

description:
I've been to India Clay Oven twice now for dinner and a few times for takeout orders. Being so far out in the Richmond district I've yet to make the trek to try their lunch buffet. Every time I leave here I'm very impressed with the obvious pride and care that goes into this establishment, it really shows in every detail of the restaurant! 

First off, the place is immaculately clean. The glasses, utensils and serve-ware are spot free, the linens are bleached, starched and neatly folded, the woods are polished. You can tell they swept, mopped and vacuumed between the lunch and the dinner crowds. Glancing into the kitchen as the waitstaff went about their business I was equally impressed with the order and cleanliness, that stainless steel shined. The health department agrees with me on this, they scored a 100! 

The same couple is always between the lobby, the kitchen and the register, overseeing the operation. They are always polite, friendly and accommodating. When picking up orders for takeout they still offer me a complimentary chai tea while I wait! The waitstaff has also been a pleasure, helpful and efficient, attentive without being obtrusive or pushy. 

And the food! Tender meats and veggies are cooked to the optimal texture and flavor. I get the impression from many lesser Indian restaurants that flavors and spices are competing for dominance, and are just thrown into the sauces willy-nilly and boiled, but not Clay Oven's. The spices in their tikka, for just one example, are well balanced and complimentary to all the other flavors on the palette, and you can tell it was simmered to creamy perfection! The naan is served still warm and fresh from the oven. 

Another thing I appreciate on the menu are the preset dinners for two. Rather than mulling over what entree you and your date are going to order to compliment each other, why not sample three or four together (with both omnivorous and vegetarian options). Plus, it's actually quite a lot of food for the modest price, enough for dinner and the next day's lunch. 

India Clay Oven is a restaurant I enthusiastically recommend to my friends. It's a ways out there in the Richmond, but totally worth the trip.
author: Brandon S.

description: Great place for lunchtime buffet!  Staff is friendly and nice.  Great value for good food!
author: Prof. X.

description: I love this place, I go here about twice a month with my wife for lunch and eat half the buffet. Service is good and I like smiley when I walk in there he is always the happiest Indian dude alive and the food is awesome. I would suggest going here to anyone.
author: William T.

description: I ordered to go from this restaurant last week for lunch.  I ordered Tandoori chicken, chicken tikka masala, and naan.  The naan was bland, tandoori chicken lacked spices (bland), and the chicken tkka masala was okay but I had better.  I do not think I will go back.
author: Manhav B.

description:
This place sucks.

Honestly, there are soooo many other options for Indian food in this city-- there is really no excuse to be frequenting this spot.  It's just another Naan n' Curry clone, in both its ingredients and the quality of the cook-staff.  There is no reason to go here.

Take the bus downtown to a whole host of other places.

I saw someone say it's the best indian food in SF.  That's possibly the most laughably absurd statement on Yelp in recent memory.  This place may be the best Indian food in the neighborhood, but hey, in the land of the blind, the one eyed man is king.
author: Michael P.

description: The best Indian buffet!  Always hot and delicious.  Super friendly staff.  They always have a good selection of buffet items.
author: Dusty B.

description:
I wanted to like this place, I really did.  I had good memories of the restaurant from when it was across the street; a tiny little hole in the wall that was nice to find in between the Chinese restaurants and the Jews for Jesus headquarters.  

I have to say the atmosphere is amazing.  It's like you're walking into an Indian 5 Star Hotel.  There is even a registration desk with a really well dressed maitre'd sitting behind the front desk (i can't even call it a counter).  It's all marble and brass fixtures.  That was the good part of my experience. 

The food and service, on the other hand, was not.  While the waiters were extremely nice, they didn't take our order for a loooooong time, and it was a production just to get the tea and wine we ordered.  When we finally ordered and the food did come, it wasn't nearly as tasty as I was hoping.  The Kashmiri lamb was essentially just lamb saag, and it was bland, though the consistency was good.  The fire prawns were overcooked, as well.  The chicken tikka maasala was actually quite good, though, if you don't mind the small portions.

The Na'an bread, both garlic and plain were also disappointing.  I could barely taste the garlic. And then there was the bill!  Somehow, prices of Indian food jumped dramatically in this city.  This restaurant was a shining example of that. 

Not what we call a bang for your buck, or taste buds!
author: Adam E.

description:
I am Indian and know what good Indian food tastes like. This IS good Indian food, not exactly like mom's but pretty darn close. We order in from here all the time and the food is delicious! If they make a mistake, they make good on it on my next order. Once they sent Spinach with Dahl instead of Cheese and next order the guy didn't charge me for it. Once I complained about not enough chicken in Chicken Tikka Masala and the guy didn't charge me for it next time. 

I have been to the restaurant too and in my opinion its one of the better setups I have seen in Indian restaurants.
author: Anu Y.

description:
After living in the Richmond for almost a year I've walked past this place a bazillion times without once stepping in to try the buffet, but today I had to take a break and get some grub on, so where better than a place with an all you can eat buffet for $8.95?? I knew I'd like the food becuase I used to frequent Tandoori Mahal down in the north beach/financial district area. 
The meat selection seemed like it is basically tandoori chicken, chicken tkka-esque chicken, and lamb curry. Not bad! All the meat was tender and flavorful and the naan was pillowy soft. I pretty much stuck with the meat options, but they have a lot of potato, pea, and spinach dishes for the vegetarian too. 
A great bargain and the service was very attentive. It feels upscale with the white tablecloths and clean interior, but its as cheap as can be!
author: Stacy T.

description:
Food was okay... The plain naan is better than cheese naan which confused me but whatever.
The reason they get really knocked by me: soooo slow. I ordered delivery to my apartment and was given a waiting time of 45 to 60 minutes. after about 75 minutes I decided to call to make sure they got my order (I ordered off eat24hours.com or whatever it's called). They apologized and told me a driver was on the way. A little over 2 hours later, my food arrived. The naan was cold, the rice was cold, the curry was not nearly as hot as it should have been. I'm not sure what the deal was there but it really bothered me considering how expensive the food was.
author: Shelby H.

description:
When it comes to pretty much any food but hamburgers (i.e. foods from a foreign land), the question arises, 'how authentic do you want it to be?'  Indian Clay Oven is a tasty restuarant in the middle Richmond that serves pretty good Indian food in a nice, white table cloth environment. 

Now personally, I don't think Indian food should ever be served on white table cloth.  The delicous sauciness of the whole affair, combined with the fact that eating it is a team sport that requires family style food in the middle the gets dumped onto plates on the outside, means that no matter what you do, you leave a big mess.  A mess that is clearly visible because of the dribbles of Massala sauce leading from the center of the table to your plate.  

That being said, the food was good, a bit pricey by about 15%, but tasty.  It came out in nice little cast metal dishes that made for a good presentation.  The small pots hid the fact, however, that there really was a lot of food there.  Combine that with the garlic naan, which was good by rather greasy, and you're pretty much full after getting through two plate-fulls.  

Overall, it was pretty much a nice, slightly Americanized, Indian meal.  There were some Indians in the place, which is always a good sign, but not many.  If you want to go out for Indian food, but want a place slightly nicer than your run of the mill $10 Indian buffet, try the Clay Oven.  But, if you just want Indian food, save yourself $15 and go to the $10 buffet.
author: Eric M.

description:
Updated review - now 5 Stars for superb service:

I ordered delivery online, but didn't receive confirmation on the order. I ended up calling to check on the order and there was some confusion. The order went to another store (one that's closer to my home). They followed up with that store and the delivery driver. They even called me back after receiving the delivery, just to make sure everything was to-order.

They didn't have to go out of their way to make sure everything was allright. Everything was fine, but they made sure I was completely satisfied. This is outstanding service!

Thank you!
author: David S.

description:
I know nothing about Indian food. I only just started eating it after what seemed to be a streak of nasty food poisoning from Indian restaurants from here to Santa Cruz and up to Sacramento.

I think their lunch buffet is great...8.95 for all-you-can-eat, and the options are great for novice eaters like me.

Because it's so conveniently located, I'll order take-out from time to time, but I've only gotten the chicken biryani...I'm too nervous to stray from a rice dish for take-out. Portions are HUGE. My food lasted me three days.

The naan is okay, but the samosas are stuffed with potato-y goodness.
author: Sachi T.

description:
Their food is pretty good, just isn't very cheap. I ordered some food from here 1 year and 2 weeks ago for a person who was in the hospital after child birth. I ordered an appetizer and 2 main dishes with some rice. The total came out to be $30. It was a last minute order because the person wasn't sure what they wanted. I got there 20 minutes later because of the difficulty in finding parking and my meal was still not ready.

After coming back home and looking at the menu once more I noticed that there was a coupon that would've saved me a lot. A coupon for half off the second main dish, a coupon the person didn't even bother applying to my order.
author: M C.

description:
I can only speak for the lunch buffet, at which the hot food was (amazingly) actually stored at a safe temperature, above 140 degrees, a rarity among Indian buffets.

Unfortunately, many of the chafing dishes were empty or mostly empty.  So, I may have picked among the least desirable leftovers.  The food was OK, nothing great.  The chicken tandoori seemed very overcooked, almost crusty on the outside.

The service, however, was first rate and the atmosphere nice for a reasonably priced Indian restaurant.  I'll try it again at a different time of day and post a second review, if India Clay Oven rates more than three stars from me.
author: Richard C.

description:
a frequented family favorite.

we love this place primarily for the all-you-can-eat buffet and the great service - honestly the guys that work here are the sweetest ever! i only come here for the lunch buffet but the food really is delicious and definitely a great value. the venue is very open and sunny. i love their chicken tikka masala! i know there are other really great indian restaurants in the city but we're pretty much regulars here
author: Kathy E.

description:
I've been there twice now and I've found it really delicious both times. The naan and puri's were very yummy. Better than a lot of other indian places in the city. the decor is nice for an indian place but the main waiter guy left a lot to be desired.. He kept giving us looks which we couldn't understand but since he kept looking at us he was easy to wave over..

my favorite: the tamarind and date sauces were nice and thick not watery like other places!
author: rukshan b.

description:
I haven't been grocery shopping in over two weeks now so my cupboards are down to dust and crumbs and mouse poo (not really the mouse thing).  Anyway, last night I really needed something to eat and I didn't feel like any of my normal delivery standards, so I opened up Delivery.com and randomly selected India Clay Oven.  

I was feeling exhausted, hence the no-go on the grocery shopping, so I decided on one of their pre-planned meals.  An hour later and I was delivered an entire grocery bag full of Indian food.  It wasn't necessarily great indian food, but the entire meal (enough for at least four people) was only $17.  If you aren't sure what to order, the meals are a good option.  I think they give you one of just about everything on the menu.
author: Katie S.

description: We love this Place!  Free fast delivery great prices and the food is sooooo good.  The first Indian we have had in SF that is actually Spicy! (Only been here 2 months).
author: Toby S.

description: I really like this place. they have a great variety of appetizers, all the ingredients are fresh and there creamy dishes are so rich and buttery.  My favorite order is chicken tikka masala, kashmiri nan, basmati rice and a mango lasi. perfect for delivery!
author: betsy P.

description: Something seems to have happened in the past 6-12 months and food quality and consistency have dropped.  It is unfortunate.  I am hoping its a fluke but we decreased our ordering frequency.
author: M O.

description:
I was really craving a special treat for myself and really wasn't sure what to get for lunch. I had just run a few errands and wanted something satisfying and good. Sushi, burger, Thai, what should I eat?

I drove down Clement not really sure of stopping any where in particular, but there was a parking spot right in front of the restaurant and I took it as a sign. It was 11 am and wow! look they open at 11 am! So from 11 am - 2:30 pm everyday you can get a buffet Indian lunch that's delicious! And how can you beat $8 for a good quality meal?!

Ok, I am really excited about their Naan. Fresh naan is brought out to your table. This is really important! The naan was soft and a little crunchy in the right places. If you go there, you'll know what I'm talking about. It makes your whole Indian food experience so much better when the naan is so hot that you have to wait for it to cool down a little before you tear a piece off to go with your curry or veggie.

What did I eat? I almost ate everything they offered on the buffet line. The food is set in pots of food with lids that are uncovered when lunch gets busier, not the regular heating stands that hold tins of food. You grab a semi-clean plate from the beginning of the line, start with rice, then veggie or fish pakora, accompanied by a cilantro type sauce, mango chutney and a tamarind sauce. Then there is the tandoori chicken which was moist and served with grilled onions. This was so good I went back for 2 more pieces. 

There was a lamb curry, with tender bite size pieces of lamb, chicken makhini (delicious, very very good), saag panner (spinach and cheese), dal made of chickpeas, mixed vegetables, salad, raita, two desserts. The saag paneer was just right - a little spicy with good texture. 

The staff are friendly, food is delicious with exceptional naan and a nice setting (skylight windows, floor to ceiling windows, clean and warm) lets me take friends here or just enjoy a nice meal by myself. The dishes could use a better cleaning, but otherwise you get a BIG BANG for your bucks here. India Clay Oven rocks!
author: Betty L.

description:
Overpriced and schma, schma, schma. I only ever got take out there. 
I went in for repeated highway robbery for just okay food until I found Great India on Geary.
author: Dee I.

description:
I really like India Clay Oven. Parking in the Outer Richmond/Clement area can admittedly be a nightmare, but once you get inside there is never a wait. The food is consistently delicious, and the service is always really good. Indian food is one of my favorite cuisines because of the spice, and India Clay Oven has been one of my favorite since I've moved to SF. 

They even deliver! I've had them deliver dinner countless times to my place in the Presidio. I like their many types of naan, and there is something for everyone on the menu, even the non-curry eaters and vegitarians. Thumbs up!
author: Glansande J.

description:
What I order:
Tandoori sampler
Chicken Tikka Masala
Naan bread
Okra.

They honestly are the best Indian place in the neighborhood, if not in SF, hands down. 

Their buffet is pretty good, too!! Me likey!!
author: Jessica O.

description:
I love the lunch buffet here -- it's so good! They have a really good variety of meat dishes, curries, and other things like tandoori chicken (which usually is a little on the dry side) and korma. It's also one of the cheapest Indian lunch buffets I've ever been to, and it doesn't skimp on quality. 

The decor here is very pretty -- I'm so happy that India Clay Oven moved to this space. It has large windows and lots of natural light flooding in. When they were just across the street, it was dark and had an eerie cold feeling. Great change of ambiance! 

Occasionally my cousins, brother, and I would get takeout for dinner from here. Sometimes getting Indian takeout gets kind of messy, especially with curry, but this place does a really nice job of wrapping things up for you sufficiently to keep your cleanup to a minimum.
author: Yvonne W.

description:
I love me some vindaloo and India Clay Oven is my choice for such a dish in my neighborhood. The restaurant itself is very nice inside but most of the time I take advantage of one of the Clay Oven's best features, they deliver... and I am sooooo lazy I can't be bothered to walk two blocks. 

I will admit that some days the food is better than others.  I'm not sure what the deal is, must depend on the cook that day.  Need to start asking, "who's working the stove today?... uh huh... okay he's good, I'll order."  But even when it's not the best, it's still mighty tasty.

I started out only eating chicken Tiki Masala and Chicken Vindaloo but Clay Oven has got me slowly working down the menu. I love Indian food, who knew!?
author: Andy A.

description:
Awesome! I loved this place. Went here for Thursday lunch buffet. 

They had really excellent food; the sauces were all very fresh-  seemingly handmade (green mint sauce, tamarind sauce, cucumber raita); their dishes were all FRESH and CLEAN (none of that oilyness you get from pre-made or canned foods) and were simply delicious. 

The staff were all extremely polite and courteous.

The place was well-lit (given, it WAS a beautiful sunny day in SF!), very clean and quite spacious. 

I will DEFINITELY be going back. Their food was simply DELICIOUS, FRESH and INEXPENSIVE ($10 lunch buffet!),  All around an excellent experience.
author: La F.

description: Delicious! I love their sag paneer, punjabi prawn curry, prawn goa curry, anything tikka masala. And they deliver... yes please!
author: Alicia E.

description: India clay oven has quite delicious food, but most everything we ordered was too spicy for our taste. Their tandoori items are quite good, but for people who can't really stand much heat don't order the spicy dishes. They have good naan and the desserts were really good. Even though i enjoyed my experience, it was quite expensive. I might go back to try the lunch buffet, but there are probably some other more inexpensive, yet just as good indian places i could try.
author: Iknowasianfood C.

description:
*UPDATE 3/21/08*

A group of us came here for a late dinner around 9:00pm and it was fantastic. My bf is indian/persian and he doesn't usually like going out to eat Indian food because he says his mom can make everything so much better, but we brought him this time and he was actually very impressed with the food. The plain and garlic naan are perfect and we loved all the 7 different curries we ordered. Nothing was a miss. The mango lassi could have used a bit more mango than yogurt, but it was still good. The service and waiters again were very friendly. 

We didn't get done eating till about 10:30 when they close. The waiters were half through clearing our table when we heard someone in the kitchen yell, "Shit!" A few of us laughed to ourselves, but I think it was because he was probably ready to go home and realized we left a bunch of dishes for him to wash. Sorry!!

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Great Indian buffet (lunch) for the price. They have lots of different curries and it's a nice place with glass/tablecloth settings. The wait staff is totally friendly and i never had to ask to refill my glass of water. They always clear your plate right away when you're done so you don't have to come back to a dirty dish. Highly recommend.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Such a beautiful space!  Lovely presentation too!  It's really too bad that I've never been enthralled by their food.  The third time isn't the charm and neither is the fourth.

The gorgeous wall paintings and art and the big windows to people watch through are great.  Even the service is friendly and kind.  Unfortunately, the food is pretty blah.  Many of the dishes almost seem like "California Indian" whatever that may be - always lacking in salt, a freshness which would normally be welcomed but instead nixes the authenticity and the hot and spiciness of the food (which is really why I'm there) 

Reminds me that Bonnie Raitt is right and India Clay Oven can't make me love them if I don't.
author: Rashmi N.

description:
The fact that I've had a distaste for Indian food ever since I got the stomach flu after eating Naan n' Curry aside-
I'm not a fan of India Clay Oven, at least the not lunch buffet. The service sucked. My friend ordered tea, which he never received. Plus we ordered naan and it took 15 minutes, 2 requests (and giving everyone else in the restaurant naan first) to get it. Come on! It was maybe half full and there were 6 waiters running around!
As for the food-the chicken masala was very boney, and the sag paneer contained no cheese that I could detect. 
Icky poo.
author: Lauren T.

description:
I've been to India Clay Oven many times and it's safe to say I'm a fan especially when I'm having one of my Indian food cravings.  Last night though, I did something that I have never done before...that is, I requested that all of our dishes be prepared, "hot."  I'm not sure that was the best idea, but it definitely made dinner quite the experience for me and my friend.  We ordered the saag paneer and the hydrabadi vegetable (both delish!).  The only criticism I have is that the naan was super oily when it came out on the table...

Overall, very good food and pretty good ambiance.  I may have lost my voice from all the spice by the end of the night, but I would say it was worth it.  Good times...
author: Alvina W.

description:
I have no idea why yelpers have rated this place very good...have no yelpers been to any other indian places in sf??  This place is pretty terrible for sf, outside of sf I'm sure it would be decent...

Anyway, the tika masala which basically everyone orders tastes like tomato soup and chicken, literally!  The naan is terrible and tastes like dough...I'm really suprised this place has even decent reviews...

In addition the price is wayyyyy too expensive...
author: christopher h.

description: Their lunch buffet wasn't too shabby, better than others in the city.  Price not bad either. $10 a person.  The only gripe I have is they charge you $2 for a soda but they don't give refills.  The bill came to our table, and my gf wanted a refill, the waiter said no refills.  Even if I wanted to pay for one, it seemed like I couldn't get a refill on soda.  They brought more naan to our table for free, but wouldn't refill the soda, I don't get it.  Also the main waiter wasn't the friendliest. Still a good buffet though.
author: Lafia M.

description:
Disclaimer: I know Indian food. I should-- I spent a month in India eating home-cooked Indian food, and b/c my grandfather is Indian, and my mom was raised in the Caribbean, I know a little something about curry.

With that said, I love India Clay Oven. After moving to SF I was overwhelmed with all of the Indian food available to me, but very disappointed with the poor quality of paneer and curries. 

Being a vegetarian, paneer is essential, and Indian Clay Oven is on point-- firm, but tasty. My Bf and I order in regularly, but once in a while we like to walk to the restaurant where we are always greeted warmly by the staff who have come to know us well. They have changed their menu since our first visit, but they still accommodate my old favorite of sahi paneer; their paneer makhani is also a good alternative to my old favorite (I tend to like red sauces) . My Bf says the chicken is always tasty and tender. Their naan has improved since our first visits-- they're softer, and did i mention their staff is wonderful?! The decor is nice, and they usually play bhangra in the evenings. I'm not a buffet gal so I can't comment on their lunch buffet.

If you live in the area, I would also recommend ordering sometimes. It can take up to an hour, but I think you get more food when you order. They also give you a two for one coupon for dining in, and the waiter always gives it back to us so that we can use it multiple times... I heart the staff here!!!!
author: Kirsti P.

description:
My daughter wanted to take me to an Indian lunch in SF before going to the Legion of Honor and De Young museums. It had been a long time since I had been to the Lincoln Park area, so I checked yelp and found India Clay Oven, near Lincoln Park, a short distance from the Legion of Honor. It got fairly favorable reviews so we tried it out.

While parking, as most places in SF, is dicey and we had to park several blocks away, it was worth the walk. This is a rather charming, nicely lit restaurant with an open, atrium area where the sun comes streaming in when the fog isn't overhead. The lunch buffet is set up just inside the door. We were seated at a table by the atrium, in the sun, with white tablecloths and a rose, in less than 10 seconds. We were eating within a minute and a $2 happy hour beer was waiting on the table when we returned from the buffet.

As with any Indian buffet, there were the usual items and a few I hadn't had before. While the fish was a bit tepid (both in temperature and spice), the lamb curry was excellent, as were most of the other offerings.

Tab came to $19. Since my daughter was buying for Father's Day, she was happy. I was happy. And we were off to the museums. I highly recommend India Clay Oven in the Lincoln Park area.
author: Calif C.

description:
Had lunch buffet here on a Sat. Worst food I ever had! 
We entered very hungry and left hungry, it was that bad. Saag paneer did not have any taste whatsoever. Chhole masala tasted like raw turmeric. Veg Pakoras were half fried. Carrot halwa was abysmal, stale, dry and tasteless. No daal on the menu. Did not taste the non-veg items, but pretty much rest of it, and it was really really bad. Called chef for a feedback and gave him an earful. I really wanted to know whether he had tasted his preparations and would he still keep them in buffet and expect people to eat. 
I was quite surprised by so many better ratings. It is beyond me, but the food I experienced in my only visit here was very very bad. And my wife felt the same, too.  
Ambience was good enough and service was okay, not great either.
author: Nikhil S.

description: I've been going here for many years. I love the food here. My favorite dishes are the paneer makhni, vegetable samosas w/ raita, and garlic naan. What i order is limited because I love these dishes so much, I don't bother trying anything else. The lunch buffet is a great deal and delicious! There are a couple things I would do to perfect a few of the items I order. I prefer raita a little bit thicker than it usually is here. I used to order the vegetable pakora also. It used to consist of larger chunks of vegetables dipped in batter and deep fried, but when I've ordered it more recently, it is mostly just small pieces of spinach in the batter deep fried, so I have stopped ordering this dish. I hate to say anything negative about this place because I love the food here, and very friendly waiters and service. I also love that they play authentic Indian music.
author: Sally B.

description: Have been eating and getting take-out from here for years. Great food and the prices are decent, in my opinion. Love the chicken tikka masala and the samosas. Love that they deliver.
author: Siobhan M.

description:
I have passed this restaurant many times and just happened to be in the neighborhood on Thursday when it opened.  A parking place appeared right in front, a sign I thought... since I love Indian food and all things Indian.  I am so glad I went inside.  I was the first person there and the $7.95 buffet lay in wait for me.  I found everything
excellent -  okay it wasn't as good as my friend's mother made during my week long stay at their home in Mumbai - but for San Francisco, it was pretty darn good.  I thought the chicken Tandori was succulent and juicy, the lamb curry spiced perfectly and the various other dishes all enticing, with wonderful sauces that I sopped happily with my huge slices of naan.  I will definitely return for the bargain lunch in the bright cheery atmosphere and I won't hesitate to try India Clay Oven when the urge for Indian food overtakes me at dinner time.
author: Carmen H.

description:
It was a sunny day in the middle of March when my friend and I hapened upon this place.  Indian was a good option!  It was lunch time and instead of the buffet, we opted to order off the menu.  That was a great idea.  Really great food.  Service was very attentive as well.  
On another day, last month, I went back with another friend and had the buffet.  Really should have ordered off the menu.  The buffet is much cheaper (about $8/ person), but it was lacking.  The deep fried stuff had gone a bit soggy from just sitting there.  The service was still very good though.  
The items on the menu may be a bit more pricey, but it's worth it.  Order from there and you won't be unhappy.  Try the veggie samosas and of course, the naan bread.
author: Lena C.

description:
Take out from here is great. The food comes in plastic containers instead of paper Chinese boxes. 

Clearly the chicken tikki masala is fab. The chicken shawarma   is excellent as well. 

Never have been to the actual restaurant though. Delivery is quick and on time. The plastic containers ensure a no mess Indian dinner.
author: elissa w.

description:
Looked like a cute place, crowded, white tablecloths, fresh flowers at each table

went in with my roommate & were taken to our table fairly quickly. the problem was, when we got to our table it had not been cleared. we had to stand awkwardly against the table beside ours while the waiter changed the table cloth & reset the silverware & plates

that was annoying & I saw them do it to 2 other tables.

the food took FOREVER to come out... i felt like everyone in the place had something to chew on except us. I didn't want to be late for work & considered leaving a few times.

Finally our food came and it was worth the wait. coconut curry shrimp was notable and would definitely order it again

the waiter gave us a plate that had a fly stuck to it, kinda hard to miss, unappetizing, and he acted really frustrated when we asked for a new clean one. 

next time I'll just order it to go.
author: c e.

description:
I kind of wish I could give 3.5 stars, so I gave them the extra half for funsies. I really, REALLY wanted to love this place because Great India has seriously sucked ass the last few times I've ordered from there and I need a new decent Indian place to deliver to my lazy self. I'm afraid that I will have to keep looking.

Not that India Clay Oven is bad by any means. But my socks weren't quite knocked off. Notable were the veggie samosas, which were probably the best I've ever had. But the naan was kind of chewy and bland, and the bengan bartha had these weird seeds in it and wasn't very tasty. 

What it was was super spicy! I asked for everything extra mild, and I'm not sure what they don't understand about the word mild. When I say mild, I mean NOT SPICY. And throwing a couple of peas on top of the rice is not a"rice with peas" dish. 

I suppose that I'll give this place another try since my boyfriend has been wanting to try it and wasn't home the night I ordered. But I really wish someone would open a fantabulous and reasonably priced Indian place in the neighborhood!
author: Amy B.

description:
My second time eating there.  Can't really recall my impressions after the first time because it was a while ago, but last night I had the chana masala and found it to be pretty awful.  

I think the reason why is b/c I ordered it spicy.   Instead of using actual spices to get it closer to what the natives eat, they simply dropped in some jalapenos to provide the kick.  As a result, the chana masala was not only distasteful, but totally jacked up my gut for the evening.

Don't waste your time on this american-ized, pricey place...they're poseurs.
author: Drew W.

description:
When it comes to buffets, I am always skeptical of the quality, and when it comes to nice looking restaurants, I expect to shell out at least $15 (im a college student, its all relative). I am happy to report that Clay Oven does not lack the quality in the buffet section and all for $8.95! 

The Food: There were such a wide variety! From lamb to chicken to vegetarian and everything was mouth watering good. The fried vegetable and fried fish were also quite delicious. I got so busy eating, now I wish I took a moment to read the actual names. One thing that I didn't like though, was the paneer in the spinach. The testure was really hard without much taste. (Frozen paneer?)

The decor: Wonderful murals on the wall, white linen table cloth, fresh rose on the table, sunlight shining through the ceiling to floor windows.

Update: Only go during lunch time buffet, dinner is expensive.
author: Jessica T.

description: I really liked the food, but the waiter drank out of the water pitcher...really...just drank out of the PITCHER...what do they do in the back....ack!!!
author: C. S.

description: I love their food..their service and their ambiance.  Parking sometimes can be tough but we usually try to get there some time after 8pm for dinner.   The staff offered us free dessert today because they thought our baby would like it...and he did!
author: Tona C.

description:
This was my second time going , last time I went was a year ago! I went with some friends for the lunch buffet and the price was reasonable less than $10 and at least 4-5 different curries to try out. I like the fact that there aren't a lot of people so like every minute the waiter will come by your table to see if you need anything. Good service. I like the fact that they will keep on bringing the naan if you want more. Tastes great in the curries. My favorite curry is the orange color looking one. 

In general there aren't a lot of selections but if you want a general taste of some indian curry and some chicken/fish/naan this is pretty good. I think you get more for your buck than say if you ordered the things off the menu. Also the restaurant is very clean, and a fancy looking restaurant with nice windows and high ceiling, a + for a restaurant. I'll be back next year if i'm busy this year.
author: Stevie C.

description: Spiciest Indian food I've ever eaten.  My Indian friend Ravi said exactly the same thing -  he was amazed that I was able to eat twice the amount that he had. The cucumber salad and yogurt sides were both a good call, as we needed something to cool our mouths.  My esophagus burns. I have a feeling this is gonna be a long night. "Indigestion is the new Black."
author: Kati K.

description: Great lunch buffet.  I think the saag paneer (spinach and cheese) is the best I've had in a very long time.  All of the other dishes were flavorful as well.  Soft and fresh naan.  My only complaint is that I wish the sauces were a bit thicker, but the flavor is there so it's cool.  Very warm customer service, which is something I appreciate.
author: Kandi K.

description: This place was recommended to me by a friend after asking where I could find authentic Indian cuisine.  I had Kashmiri Chicken and my date had Velvet Chicken.  Both were quite tasty, however I was a little disappointed that I had opted for the Medium Spiciness.  It wasn't as spicy as I would have liked.  The place has a truly lovely ambiance and it would be a great place to visit either in jeans or slacks, whatever the occasion.  The service was good, the food was a little more expensive than I would have liked, but overall it was a very good dinner.  I give you four stars, absoloodle!
author: Walter B.

description:
It's not worth buying anything from their menu because most of the dishes are in the buffet.  The buffet is pretty good with a lot of options, but they don't seem to replenish enough.  Some of the pots are either almost empty or has been sitting out for a while.

I think the buffet is really good, but you have to go right when the food is fresh.  The question is - when is the food fresh?
author: Annie S.

description: When make curry with large helpings of cream and clarified butter, you'll never end up with a bad curry. You won't end up with a good curry either.
author: Vinit P.

description:
The most delicious Indian buffet I know of! :)

This place once made my mother say that she wished she could swim in the vat of chicken tikka masala with her mouth open.

My family loves Indian food and we're always looking for new places to try, but for years this one has been on the top of my list.  My mother and I used to go to India Clay Oven when it was located in the much smaller and less attractive venue it's in now.  Some places get worse when they move to nicer locations, but in this case the quality of the food hasn't been sacrificed at all.
author: Allison D.

description:
Recently I have been traveling the city sampling various indian buffet lunch restaurants trying to find the best one.
Well, I've found it. This particular indian restaurant, India Clay Oven on Clement Street is by far the best indian buffet you will ever have. Not only is it inexpensive (~$10), especially for what you're offered, but the food is fantastic!  It's colorful, fresh and oh so flavorful. Every other indian buffet I've gone to the lamb in the lamb curry was chewy and the tikki masala tasted like milk and tomato sauce; not at Indian Clay Oven. Every dish had the freshest brightest flavor you'll ever find. Spicy lentils, Aloo Ghobi to die for and super yummy tandoori chicken. This place I highly recommend. If you don't live near the avenues it's absolutely worth the drive out to 25th and Clement. Heck, it's worth a crowded 38-line bus ride down Geary!
author: robert p.

description:
India Clay Oven is a great place for a nice casual lunch. The buffet is perfect with a wide variety of dishes but also not too much that you get overwhelmed. This buffet lunch for $10 is just what the doctor ordered on a gloomy day. The dining room has great natural light but can get a little noisy if it fills up (usually just when there is a large party).Too spicy? Cool things down with a tasty mango lassi. 

Street parking can be a little bit tough in the neighborhood. Free parking two blocks down at the lot, with validation.
author: R K.

description:
This is definitely a "classier" Indian food establishment.  The decor is beautiful, and the food is presented in traditional indian-style dishes.

The food is pretty good, though you can find food that is just as good, if not a little better, and at a slightly lower cost, if you're willing to give up a little of the classy atmosphere.

I prefer Great India Restaurant on Geary for the food and price.  For a nicer atmosphere and decent Indian food, I will go to India Clay Oven.
author: Vicky M.

description:
Great lunch buffet. 

Recent favorite: Fish tikki masala 
Excellent. Best I've had in town. 
I also really like their Kashmiri chicken, saag dishes, and vegetable masala.

The only thing is that the waiter may ask you if you want some extra sauces without mentioning that they cost extra. I like my servers to be more up front. That instance was my first dinner experience there. 
But other than that, its my current indian jam.
author: Eve L.

description: I've been going to this neighborhood restaurant for years. It's reliably good, reasonably priced, efficient service. And they deliver if you live in their delivery range. Go with people you can share dishes with. There are many great choices.
author: Francesca P.

description: ordered pickup. they said 20-25 mins. came after 20 mins. it's been over 40 mins since I called. they obviously forgot to put in my order.
author: Lawrence K.

description:
My favorite Indian Restaurant and I've gone to about 3 in SF! Didn't know about it until an Indian co-worker brought me there! And you can usually tell if a restaurant is good and authentic when people of that culture/nationality/background go there! (Yes, people if you don't see Asians in that Chinese restaurant, it's probably not good...same with any other restaurant!)

Love the Chicken Mak-knee (not sure how to spell it so I spelled it phonetically) It's soo super good!! You can order it mild or spicy!

The restaurant itself has been redone. It used to be cute and across the street, but now it's HUGE and GRAND! There's even a big entertainment section in the back for parties! 

What impressed me was how super clean this restaurant was! And you know that letter grade for quality that's posted on the door/window entrance area?? Well, I swear they got an A and a score of 99! That's impressive! Service was good.

I will admit it is a bit pricey, but worth it when I have an Indian craving.

But because parking can be difficult I usually order in and sometimes the deliveries are real quick!
author: M R.

description:
Vegie review:
Pretty tasty,  it was a bit mild for my taste, but it was something new.
Lots of nuts and raisins, which gets it up a star, along with the excellent ambiance.
The service seemed very rushed,  but they were competent as well.
Ultimately though the food was a bit mild, and VERY rich,  my stomach is going to be a bit quirky for a bit, I don't want to imagine how much ghee I just consumed.
author: Chris M.

description:
Cannot believe people on Yelp gave this place a 3.5 star!
Yes the workers are indian but they seriously they are just selling s*** to people who obviously do not know what real indian food is
Indian food has never been this bad. Absolutely overpriced for the food's quality AND quantity. Service was horrible to the MAX. 

Its basically a restaurant to trick people who havent had real indian food in their lives.

cannot believe how i see review about people liking the naan and the chai.
The naan was dry with little flavor. Chai also had no flavor and tasted so fake.

Maybe it was the time of the day I went and the good chef was not there but this place is one of the worse restuarants i ever went to.
author: Daniel X.

description: The best Indian food I have found in SF, so far.  The onion bhaji is too sweet and sugary for me, but the veg pakora are good.  The lamb curry is nice and the dhal is good, too. I still miss the curry back home (in England) but this place will see me through.
author: C J M.

description:
Great chicken tika, rice pilaf and nan (get extra nan!)  Be sure to let them know if you don't like it spicy!  WARNING:  can be addictive.  

p.s. 99% of the time the food is freaking great -- but every now and then it just isn't.  Remember what day you ordered and don't order on that day -- I think it's one bad cook.
author: r b.

description: Very good.  Ordered delivery to my brother's house.  Saag Paneer and Tikka Misala are great.  Not cheap.
author: Paul L.

description:
There are many things I miss about living in San Francisco.  Chief among them is the lack of cheap, decent Indian food in San Diego.  For some reason many Indian restaurants in SD feel the need to overcharge for staples.

My brother-in-law took me here for the 10 buck lunch buffet.  The lamb curry alone would have made it worth it, but the chicken and garlic naan set it over the top.
author: Poutine G.

description: The marsala is okay here it could be spicier.  The place has a nice atmosphere with many different kinds of taste to offer.  A bit pricey, but the food quality, taste, and amount is fairly given.
author: Cristina G.

description:
Came here for dinner late last night. The wait staff totally rushed us through ordering and getting us to finish our meal. 

The chicken curry (medium spicy) was more like mild and there wasn't enough sauce for the amount of chicken. 

Just saw the special on yelp and we ordered two entrees and didn't get one half off...

$50+ meal for two, not worth it, probably won't go back.
author: Cassandra T.

description:
I have eaten here many times.  The $7.95 buffet is the best in the city.  In particular, they server thier Naan freshly cooked, which is very rare for indian buffet.

I also highly recommend the tika masala.
author: Shawn L.

description:
One of the best Indian food buffets I've been to, but I don't eat much Indian food to begin with so I might be trippin' but it tasted ok and I didn't get sick. =]

Recommendations: Lunch buffet and Mango Lasi.
author: Michael C.

description:
I like this place a lot.  The staff has always been courteous and the food always hits the spot.  The ambiance gives you a good vibe, even though it looks like a yuppy hang out.  I prefer this location to the last one they had right across the street.  The only  item(s) I haven't ordered is the lamb because it scares my girly man palette.  But the chicken tandori, masala, palak, curry, I love it all.  

They pay attention to the details like the rice, naan, lassi, the complex blends of spice in the entrees, you name it.  They make it special.  

There's another location in San Mateo and that place is just as good, though it's a bit stuffy in there.
author: optimus r.

description: I usually order take out but My friends decided to go out instead. It was really dark inside and hard to read the menu but thank god for window seats. I ordered the chicken korma, rice and onion naan for my boyfriend and It was pretty good but I still like aslam rasoi's.
author: Shirley Z.

description: For Indian Buffet, this is the best San Francisco has to offer. I repeat for  Indian Buffet only. Its from 12-2  daily and has a large selection of fresh dishes. The service is friendly, maybe a little too friendly if your a woman so watch out! But I do like this place and am still trying to convince my boyfriend to try it out cuz he says he doesnt eat indian food because it makes his clothes smell sweaty! A small price to pay for delisciousness.
author: M K.

description: This place was a good place for me to try Indian food for the first time in the city. I've never been a huge fan, but this place is changing my mind. The lunch buffet is a great deal, all you can eat and great food in a really nice white linen table clothed environment. I'm definitely coming back here when I have a huge appetite! Also the plain Naan was great, bc I used to snack on it as a kid. I had never had the plain kind in a restaurant, so I never knew what it was called till today!
author: Erika T.

description: Love, LOVE, Love the FOOD!.. Indian Clay Oven is perfect for a cheap date. I went with my bf for the lunch buffet, after going the previous week with my classmates for our class project. The service was fantastic! The waiters totally recognized me from before. They have a simple variety of food, some of which was a little spicy, but nothing over the top. From the moment you walk into the Indian Clay oven restaurant the music, decor, and authentic vibe will put a great smile on your face. I will eat here again and I recommend it to anyone questioning Indian cuisine, or just looking for a new restaurant to try.
author: Felicia R.

description: This is the best Indian food in town! And one of my favorite restaurants of any kind. The food is Delicious and the lunch buffet is fantastic! The staff is friendly and the decor is very nice - always with fresh red roses. I go frequently by myself and sometimes with friends, we always enjoy our experience there.
author: Maria C.

description:
For those of you looking for a quick answer: the food was good, service was friendly and quick, nice atmosphere, but a little pricier than expected.

I heard about the India Clay Oven from a woman in my building when I moved in a couple weeks ago. "The best Indian food in the city" she said. My roomie and I looked over the menu online first and called my Indian friend to find out what the hell some of the stuff was, because I had never had Indian food before. We finally decided to take the walk down to the Clay Oven to just see what would happen. 

When we walked pass the window, I was like "damn, white cloth napkins" because the woman in my building had said "it doesn't look like much..." well I was a little nervous because we are both on a budget, but we went in anyways. 

Very nice staff from the start and we were able to order quickly since we had already looked at the menu at home. We ordered the vegetable samasa as an appetizer and when this flat, crackerish bread came out, we were a little confused. We were like "Is this the samasa? or the nan? what is this? we are so white." I guess it was something complimentary because our side salads and the samasa came out shortly after. 

My "mixed green salad" was lettuce, cucumber and tomato, while cailin got the cucumber salad. There were some sauces on the table for the samasa so we just continued using them on our salads. We had no idea if they were for teh salads or what, but figured it was ok. I really like the mango sauce and she really liked the yogurt. The cheese nan was really good too.

I got the chicken do piaza and cailin got the vegetable biryani. they looked at me funny since I didn't want rice to go with mine, but I was thinking about all the starches I already ate, I really didn't need the rice, I used the rest of my nan to scoop up the sauce. The chicken was pretty good, but I was hoping it to be a little spicier, the waiter didn't ask how hot we wanted it. the biryani was good too, but again somewhat mild. I guess you have to ask for hot.

When the check came, the prices were just in a list so we kind of had to figure out what was what. We couldn't figure out what the additional double listing of $1.50 was, but thought maybe it was the two sauces since the waiter had asked us if we wanted sauces with the appetizer when we ordered. So that was kind of a drag and it turned out to be like $22 with tip, but we both brought some home.

In the end, it was a fun first experience, but little things like the mild food and extra costs brought down my rating. I will probably go again, but maybe after I try somewhere else first.
author: liz c.

description:
The boy enjoys Indian food to an absurd degree and even he had to agree with me that was the chai was the best mix we've had in the city. We ordered the same dishes we usually do - the palaak paneer, garlic naan, samosas, any type of vegetarian sample platter, and a vegetarian masala dish.  Again, while I've gotten to know the standard fare found in the richmond and sunset (delicious, cheap, about $15 for the two of us) I was surprised again with the bill - Maybe $5-7 more including the sample platter.  

This place definitely delivers when it comes to food (a bit better than the smaller joints in the neighborhood), presentation, and service (what, I don't have to get up and make my own drink?).  Based on the other reviews, I won't try their buffet, but this is definitely a great place for a chill, sit down, slightly fancier Indian meal.
author: Desiree C.
