description: I've been here many times and I've brought family,friends and co-workers and everyone has always enjoyed the food. It's a good deal for a buffet. I liked the fish pakora,tandoori chicken, the chicken with the potato and the spinach dish.I like that the Naan is fresh made and the waiters are polite. Parking is ok around 11am but gets worse around 12:30.
author: Theresa W.

description: We ate a late lunch there and it was 100% yum. Great service and pretty fast. We got the non-veg. dinner for two and it was more than enough. Super naan!
author: Isabella M.

description: I used to *love* this place and get their chicken tikka masala all the time. Then, a few months ago, it suddenly changed. The chicken tikka masala became watery, and it was pretty obvious that the chicken had been frozen and then pre-cooked. I am so sad that I have lost a good restaurant.
author: Jessica P.

description: Lunch buffet was a good price but there are not as many choices as Curry Village. I loved the decor, the view and how clean it was. Our waters were constantly filled but the chai tea tasted too sweet and watered down (it was like drinking a diet version of chai lol) Every time we got up to go get more food...you can't tell from the pictures but it's actually a bit awkward walking back to your table because the tables are too close together. A child at another table almost ran into me when I was walking back to my table. The food was good but, with the limited choices. You would think it'd be easier for them to keep them filled up constantly but the two times, we got up for more food and always ended up "scraping" the bottom just to get a lil bit of rice. The bread was fresh and crispy (samosas and garlic naan do not come with the meal - they must be ordered separately.) Overall, it was a good meal and a good price except that I ended up spending more here because I had to pay for samosas. If we had been at Curry Village, the samosas were part of the buffet experience and they just have more variety  there AND I really liked that they also had fruit for dessert. The dessert was limited and there was no fruit. Overall good experience because service was polite and fast. 3 stars
author: Rachel A.

description: Chicken tikka masala or lamb korma  - to die for! The staff are very corteous and attentive. The food is great, the atmosphere is awesome. Love this place! Been here a hundred times and definitely going back again!
author: Suzanna G.

description:
Finally visited this place after years of driving by and saying "Mmm, I gotta try this place." (My own private Groundhog Day)...

We ordered the Fish Pakora ($4.25) appetizer to start; fried morsels of fish, very tender and flavorful, something I would order again for sure. Mango dipping sauce was very good with these.

We then had the Chicken Tikka Masala ($11.95), served in a red sauce which was supposed to be hot but was midly spicy. Very tasty though and sauce was great with rice.

And finally had the Punjabi Lamb Curry ($10.95) ..now this one was HOT! We had asked the waiter for the hottest they had and one of the busboys wore out his shoes refilling our water glasses. You know something is hot when conversation dies out and all you hear is panting and "Goddamn!" and the sounds of drinking water.

The interior of the restaurant is very nice, service was as good as it gets (although our waiter's thick accent and rapid delivery made me throw out a few "Um, excuse me's") parking is ok just avoid Clement, better trying side avenues.
author: Steve K.

description: Came here for the lunch buffet with the husband and the mother-in-law the other day. The food was ok - not better or worse than other Indian food I've had. I was disappointed because they didn't have the aloo gobi (my all time favorite) but they had another vegetable dish made of potatoes and bell peppers which was good. Their tandori chicken was pretty good compared to another Indian place I've had. Very flavorful and the chicken was tender. The eggplant was also good. My favorite was the chicken tiki masala and the naan which I used to soak up the sauce. The naan comes to you nice and warm and very good.
author: Lang T.

description:
I'll admit it. I was a pretty bad girl this weekend. By "pretty bad" I mean "pretty wasted" and by "this weekend" I mean "the past three years". Needless to say, by Sunday I was spent. I was done. I was home. Watching movies. And drying out. 

After just such a "weekend", the one thing that makes me feel better is a big, glutonous dinner with friends. So I rounded up Matt capital R and Starla and demanded we stuff ourselves with indian food. Luckily, they are wonderful enablers...er...friends and agreed that indian delicacies should indeed be stuffed into our pieholes. Stat.

I then demand (yes, I can be quite demanding from time to time) that we go directly to Great India. As luck would have it, we couldn't find parking on Geary and as luck would have it, Starla is too lazy to walk that extra block from her crib to get to Great India. Just when Matt and I thought we were going to have to cut a bitch for some parking, Starla suggests we meet at India Clay Oven instead. 

Starla is my new hero. India Clay Oven rocks, no RAWKS, my americanized indian food-loving world. I am no fan of the spicy, chunky, or exotically-seasoned indian you're inclined to find at Zante's or, hell, in India. I like the rich, the creamy, the subtle flavors with an intense burst of authentic flavors here and there. ICO is run by the same people who own India Garden on Folsom and it shows. This location has a huge, crisp, clean dining room with dark wood and lots of windows. Real table linens bring this place up a notch from many standard indian joints in the city. Service is fine, if not a touch formal for an indian restsaurant. 
We had the veg pakora, papudam, veg korma, tandoori chicken, and saag paneer. All of it was perfection, especially the korma and the saag. You will not find any oily messes here. I don't know what their secret is but they somehow manage to keep all the fat blended into the dish, so there aren't pools of still oil floating on top of your food. You know what that means: Second helpings all around.
We'll be back but we're taking MUNI next time. Because driving around for hours, looking for parking, in the car-accident vortex that is the Outer Richmond makes me want to cut a bitch.
author: Autumn K.

description: Ooohh Clay Oven, should I pronounce 'you' the best Indian resto in town? Well, there are still many great Indian restaurants waiting for me to try, so maybe not now. But I went here today and I LOVE IT! Talking 'bout atmosphere and interior, this place is GREAT! and it was surprisingly inexpensive! Lunch buffet for $10 is a great deal. Chicken Tandoori is better than anywhere else I've tried so far. Kheer and carrot pudding is a heaven match ( for me). All the curries are tasty. Yes, they have waiter service and a nice one indeed. Such a pleasant experience, obviously I'm in love. :D
author: Marlis T.

description: My dad is an eclectic dude. You wouldn't call him classy, but occasionally he busts out with some white-napkin shit. He digs India Clay Oven. It's generically tasty, kinda pricey Indian food for white people, pretty much. There's nothing especially spectacular about it, but it's dressed up with fancy accoutrement and attentive service, and it's definitely good enough to eat a whole lot of it. Which we usually do.
author: Megan W.

description:
this place used be a bar & grill calld "Court yard".
it was pretty trashy.
and Clay Oven was right cross a street.
I like this place, they fixed-up very nice.
but a bit pricy.
I took my boys and they were all right.
we love hot shit like Indian.
Boys want hot & spicy but I always ask mild.
there is a waiter lookin Oriental, he asked me that I am Japanese.
I said yes.he proudly said that he knew it.
why he ask?!
He said he from Nepal.
He has seen many Japanese.
that's it.
author: Nobu K.

description:
When you hear $7.95 Indian lunch buffet, you've got to be a little suspicious.  I'm not a huge Indian fan in the first place because, in my past experiences, you leave reeking of curry and not really remembering anything significant from the meal that is doing its damnedest to follow you around.  However, all it took was one trip to India Clay Oven to change my perspective.  They had everything from tandoori chicken to vegetable masala, and it was all delicious, diverse, and bottomless!!  As a finale, there was a delectable rice pudding along with doughballs swimming in syrup to put the finishing touches on the meal.  The spaciousness of the restaurant, which could easily seat 200 people, prevented the curry from saturating my clothes and the large windows brightened the room with sunshine.  The wood accents were lovely and they had single red roses at every table that complemented the wood while adding a romantic quality.  Quite the lunch special experience at a pleasant restaurant nestled in the Richmond... definitely worth another trip!

UPDATE:  The dinner was fantastic as well!  The ambiance really shines through as the lights dim... very romantic & warm.  They have these great dinners that come with everything from the naan to the chai.  Of course, we left stuffed and happy!
author: Tara G.

description: Indian Clay Oven has gone way downhill.   This used to be our 2nd favorite indian food restaurant and a place we would order delivery from at least twice a month.   We noticed that the food stopped being consistently good but the last straw was about two weeks ago.  We had friends over that love indian food and were excited to have a feast from ICO.  Well the order came late with one missing entree, no appetizer and two missing orders of naan.  The delivery guy told us it "wasnt his problem he just delivers the food, that if we have a problem we need to call the restaurant."  He then ripped the money out of my girlfriend's hand and took off running!!!  And upon reviewing the order, we were overcharged on top of that.  I will NEVER again give business to this unprofessional restaurant and will tell everyone I know to avoid it as well.  You should too.
author: J L.

description: I have to review one special item here.... totally unexpected choice... I was not feeling to hot, i wanted some soup, i dont know what i read wrong on the menu, but to my delight i ordered this chicken soup... it was FANTASTIC. Take your typical chicken tikka-masalla sauce (spelling wrong im sure) add in some crazy spices that make it fire hot and whamo, thick, delicious, spicy soup... enough for a meal, only $3. A must try for a soup lover! Everything I have had there is always good.
author: Rachel L.

description: Best Indian in the city. If you ask for spicy, they don't look you over while silently noting your English features and assume you mean medium-spicy. I like whatever I'm eating when my eyes are watering. Their lentil soup isn't exciting but other than that, I have no complaints. The masala, daal, pakora and samosas are exactly what you'd want them to be if you appreciate Indian food.
author: Sylvia P.

description: I've been here for lunch, and for dinner.  The lunch buffet is pretty decent, considering the spectrum of food that usually is hiding beneath the covers of chafing dishes at your usual corner curry shop. However, the dinner was much more disappointing.  Here's a handy tip for any indian-restaurant waiters who might be reading: When someone says "spicy," please assume they mean it.  I am *so* tired of having to say "this isn't spicy enough."  Okay?  How many indian restaurants must I train?  I know that my level of preferred spiciness approaches (or exceeds) the "Professional Driver, Closed Course, Do Not Attempt at Home" level - but c'mon, *some* amount of heat would be appreciated.  Especially since one of the dishes we ordered (the Punjabi chicken curry) even says 'hot' on the menu?
author: Stephan W.

description: My friend and I were not super impressed with this place.  They do have a new larger location directly across the street from their old location. The new spot is interesting because it has big tinted floor-to-ceiling front room windows that give the place a weird eighties feel.  The floor felt a bit greasy and slippery to me.  I recall that we had Lamb Saag, which was gamey, rubbery and fatty.  Maybe we just went on an "off" night, but with all the decent Indian restaurants in town, I probably would decline to go back.
author: Rick H.

description:
First, it's interesting that it's been one year since I wrote my first review about India Clay Oven.  Now, I'm writing an update to that review!

I just had lunch there on Friday, 2/12/2010, and am impressed by their consistency.

I've been there for their buffet lunch quite a few times over the past month and-a-half now, and early on I noticed a new change:  they have explanatory notecards that describe what's in the dishes that are served up that day.  This is a nice little touch that helps diners old and new alike who like to know what goes into a dish.

No, we're not talking recipes, but they say that the Chana Masala is spicy garbanzo beans, or that the Saag Paneer is cooked spinach with homemade cheese cubes, you get the drift.  Before, you may have wondered, "What do they put in these dishes?"  Not in a bad, pejorative way, just a curiosity about Indian-style cooking.

Their tandoori chicken is still done quite well and it isn't dry at all, unless it is on the bottom of the pan and the sterno has heated it dry.  In an effort to keep their food warm and moist, they've taken to covering the opening with aluminum foil and leaving enough of an opening so that you can reach the food with the tongs or spoon.  This is especially true of their pakoras, the rice pilav, and the tandoori chicken.  Those do tend to dry out faster from heat and exposure.  The other dishes are in sauces, so they are not covered.  Their green salad is fresh and crisp, not dry and lifeless.  I've yet to see them use any ingredients that aren't fresh or are subpar.  They do a good job with their food preparation, which is VISIBLE, not IMPLIED.

Again, their service is really good and unobtrusive, and they are family friendly.  I have seen kids (and some babies) in tow and they seem to be okay with the food, too.  In my previous review, I mentioned that their curry isn't too overpowering, and that's held true.  Although, I must say that lately I've experienced a slightly sore throat the day after.  That's probably more me than anything else, so don't knock them for that.

If you're looking for good Indian/Pakistani food, then you should come here.  It's a much better dining experience.  The other Indian buffet place, Great India, just doesn't cut it.

Their interior is somewhat gloomy and I don't see many diners in their when I walk past.  Having eaten there before, they do have quite a bit of improving to do if they want to give India Clay Oven a run for its money.
author: E L.

description:
I am sad that there are other reviewers who had bad experiences here, because I have been a loyal and frequent customer for the past 10 years.  
Back when they were across the street, my friend Shawn and I came for the buffet 1ce a week without fail.  When they moved to their current larger location, we LOVED the new space and continued to patronize them.  Their buffet is an AMAZING bargain--all you can eat for $9--they definitely lose money on us!
I take ALL my guests here (veggie and meat eater alike) and have never had anyone be disappointed.  
They recognize me/us and greet us every time we come, when I order by phone they greet me like an old friend; I literally have no complaints about the food or the customer service.
I'm a HUGE Indian food fan, too, and have been to every Indian restaurant in SF in my 13 years here, and aside from India Oven in the Haight, this place wipes them all up!
I'm on my way to India in a week and will have *real* Indian to compare to, but my suspicion is that they are as authentic as they come.
When I told the owner I was going to India, he told me that his entire family is from Rajasthan (where I'll be), so I look forward to the tastes of home while there!
If you had a bad experience, give them another chance.

PS.  A few things to note about the food:  it's occasionally QUITE spicy, depending on the chef that day.  In the buffet line, the veggie pakora tray is sometimes only heated by one burner so grab your pakora from the bottom of the tray to assure warmth.  The nan is not like other nan I've tasted--here the consistency is like a cross between a homemade flour tortilla and a pancake (which I LOVE) so if you're looking for a more cracker/crepe style nan, you might be disappointed.  
Also, the other 3 restaurants, though owned by the same company, have left me unsatisfied when I've gone.  Somehow, the food is just not as good (though it's easily been 5 years since I've visited any others).
Hope this helps!
:)
author: D C.

description: 5 words that personify India Clay Oven; Best Bang for your Buck! I'm talking of course about the criminally cheap $9.99 lunch buffet they have every day. The food is great and they rotate their dishes often. The service is always nice and polite while the dining room is always kept formal and clean. But seriously, $9.99 for this kind of excellent quality Indian food is ridiculous!
author: Raymond P.

description: Great food.  I have been dining here since 1999.  The food is always great and the owners are very nice.  The new location is very nice.  Think the prices jumped a bit since they were in that super rundown building across the street.  But that is to be expected.  The buffets over the weekend were my favorite thing.  Haven't been to the buffet in over 2 years but I am figuring it is almost the same.  They used to have about 5 meat dishes and 5 vegetarian dishes which was great since I didn't eat any meat at the time.  Their sag paneer is great!
author: Lauren B.

description: I came here one afternoon for the lunch buffet. I'm very open to trying all kinds of new foods, so tried practically everything they had to offer. There wasn't one thing that I didn't like, but their Tandoori chicken with the creamy, mild spicy sauce is by far the best! The service was good: kept refilling our drinks every so often and to see if we wanted more naan. It looks like a semi-classy restaurant when you walk in because there is a rose in a vase at every table. All this for about $11, you can't complain.
author: Jeff L.

description:
My favorite Indian restaurant as it has good food and good service and very clean and nice.  The good Indian food can be found in many places, but to find good service and nice place is rather hard.
Buffet for lunch is a bargain.
author: Miinno N.

description: I am surprised so many people gave this a bad review. I love it! My boyfriend doesn't like Indian so it became my "birthday restaurant" until I discovered they deliver! It is a bit pricey but I order a few things and I get dinner and lunch for a few days. I looove the chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, palak paneer with raita and mango chutney, mmmm, so good. They used to be in a dark space across the street, their new location is much more inviting, although less authentic.
author: Emily W.

description:
we went there during golden gate 75th celebrations for a quick dinner.
the vegetarian menu was very limited. the samosas tasted ok. the entrée did not come with rice and we ordered rice pulav separately ( which had no salt at all) and salt and pepper was not put in our table also. it tasted like the rice had been cooked in the morning and had been reheated in the microwave before being served to us.
the vegetable jalfrezi was all dry and tasteless.. we ended up wasting a good portion in spite of being hungry as we felt sick after a couple of spoons..may be the gravies are not as bad... i would definitely never recommend this place to vegetarians..
for this price, having a fancy setting is not enough..quality food should be provided too!
author: Srividhya P.

description: We showed up for dinner and ate in that big glass window by the sidewalk.  The staff was courteous and prompt.  I heard that the Bombay food was mediocre.  But I always like to try something new, so I concentrated on the Himalayan dishes.  It was a great twist, and helped me broaden my idea of what is Indian.  The Himalayan food tasted great!
author: David D.

description: The lunch buffet kicks ass - it has the largest variety I've ever seen for a buffet.  The dinner menu is extensive and I have yet to order something I didn't like.  It's a little spendy, but the ambiance is nice and the staff is very friendly.  This is my favorite Indian restaurant in the neighborhood.
author: Dwigt S.

description:
been meaning to actually go inside and sit down to eat, not a bad place.  the food was very tasty but you definitely want to go with people who will eat a lot so that you can order many dishes to try out.  

i didn't want to try the same dishes so i was alittle more adventurous at this place.  i recommend the lentil soup (Dal soup) but be for warned, if you were expecting lentils in the soup then might be disappointed.  the soup was tasty, make sure you have a spoonful with a bite of cilantro.  it makes the soup that much better.  the soup had a hint of spice to as well making it oh so very tasty.  

we ordered lamb do piaza, chicken tikka massala, prawn do piaza, and bhindi masala.  the lamb dish was great, it was so delicate and not gamie at all (i guess i like lamb a little gamie).  the tikka massala was good as usual.  the prawn do piaza was was the best i think.  the shrimp wasn't over cooked and spices were great.  i think the bhindi masala was my least favorite.  the okra was over cooked and mooshy, i like my veggies with a bite.   

i know by reading my last paragraph you wonder why i gave this place even a four but really service is great, food was overall really good.  i was just being nit picky so you can get a real review of the food.  

i would say this indian restuarant is a bit more upscale meaning they have white table cloth and candles.  

to sum up, be adventurious try new dishes and the worst is you might not like it =)
author: junie k.

description:
The husband and I were feelin' a little lazy and searched for an indian restaurant that delivers near our house. So, we decided to enlist the help of Yelp and found India Clay Oven. It feels good to know that Yelp always comes thru. 
So, we checked out the restaurant's website and noticed that we could order online. How great is that? I love the fact that I can read the descriptions and click on what I wanted and how many I wanted with as much time as I needed. Then after entering in my credit card, a confirmation number came up. I did call the restaurant to verify that my order came thru, and it did. In about 30 minutes, my food came, piping hot.
We ordered the vegetarian samosas to start. Nothing really to write home about. Good, fresh, and warm. We also ordered 1 garlic naan and 1 kashmiri naan. Mmmmm I love garlic naan, but the kashmiri naan was so delicious, I kept stealing pieces off my husband's plate! The sweet, cherry filling is out of this world! I can never order indian food without ordering Matter Paneer (green peas and cheese in spicy gravy) which was very, very tasty. And the vegetable korma left a lingering spice in my mouth which I still remember very fondly. But I think the dish that made our meal was probably the vegetable biryani. The rice was full of vegetables, potatoes, raisins and nuts! The crunch of the nuts were a big and happy surprise!  
We loved the food so much, we were licking our plates (don't hate...you know you do it too!) We will definitely be ordering from here more.
author: Jan Z.

description:
i have found my go to indian place and i have turned my bf into an indian food fan

we ordered the pakoras, cheese naan, garlic naan (gotta have that for sure), lamb korma, and fish vindaloo

we didnt even finish half of what we ordered...only b/c we were so stuffed...it was fantabulous

service was great and i like how the space is so open with all the windows

next time we're coming for the tandoori chicken..it smelled so good
author: Alice K.

description: Expensive, but oh so yummy.  My favorite Indian in town.  Go hang out with the bartender in the back while you wait for your take-out.  He's got great stories.
author: Monika M.

description:
For my first time trying Indian food I have to say it was just OK.
We had a birthday dinner for a friend of mine and her sister did the ordering.  
On the plus side I have to admit that last nights meal has left me with the urge to try the food at India Clay Oven again.  Hopefully since I will order for myself everything won't be so spicy.
author: Jaime G.

description: Great Indian food, good prices... Good location... And they deliver! Yay!
author: Lindsey S.

description: Knowing I love Indian food, my husband surprised me for Valentine's Day and took me to India Clay Oven. I was excited, I love a good Indian meal. Unfortunately, the excitement ended there. While the venue itself is lovely, the food just doesn't stand up to the decor or the prices. The saag paneer- one of my favorite dishes- was bland and tasteless. Dinner for the two of us came out to $75+. They do get points for service, but that isn't enough bring me back again.
author: Megan C.

description: First of all, my roommate orders India Clay Oven every other week for delivery.  He had heard horror stories of going to eat there -- like, the service is bad.  The solution?  Go there for lunch and get the lunchtime buffett.  You pay about 8 bucks, and the selections are varied and excellent -- I especially liked their vegetable pakoras.
author: Tim G.

description: yummy, friendly, and the lunch buffet rivals the ones in Cambridge MA! I really like the front room, and the variety is great.
author: dj z.

description:
i can only speak to delivery here... 

timing: about an hour. 
food: really just so-so. got the chicken makhani and the aloo matter, along with naan and rice. nothing extraordinary. 

would much rather get delivery from rotee in lower haight.
author: Sharon C.

description: Surprisingly pretty good food. Better than what I thought when we decided to come here and eat. All the food are good, especially the saag and the garlic and cheese naan. The price isn't too bad either, pretty much San Francisco price. Maybe next time, I should go for the buffet.. see if I would enjoy it.
author: Daisy S.

description: I really really don't like this place.  The food is blah, the service is too over attentive and not very nice at the same time...weird huh?  I'd rather travel great lengths to find better Indian food than ever eat there again.
author: erin f.

description: The ambience is fine here, but it is too expensive, the portions are small and the food really isn't all that great. I came here on a date once and doubt I will ever return. We were one of only three tables occupied, and we hardly ever saw our server when we needed him, but he was all over us when we didn't. I understand the lunch buffet is a pretty good deal, but I doubt I'll ever give it the chance because my experience at dinner was so poor. Go elsewhere.
author: Lance J.

description: The service was mediocre and confusing, but the food was some of the best I've ever had.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
it was yummy, not spicy and not bland.

but as others have said, it was not packed. but it it is a cute little restaurant!
author: Monica R.

description: Food's not too bad, though seems overpriced for the portion.  I've only eaten at the restaurant once.  Never order for delivery!  The order took nearly 2 hours to get to me, and when I called to ask where it was, my call was transferred to the driver, who yelled at me and hung up. EXTREMELY rude and unprofessional.  You're better off ordering from India Garden Restaurant (in same family) on Folsom.
author: Marissa B.

description: My husband and I ate at the India Clay Oven on Thursday night and were very disappointed.  We love indian food and were excited to try a new place. We ordered the lamb saag, chicken vindaloo, dal makhni, and bhindi masala.  Most of the dishes were much too salty which covered up the flavor of the other spices.  The chicken vindaloo was actually very bland.  This is a dish that should be served spicy or spicier.   We also ordered the aloo paratha which never came.  We tried the papadums which were good, but not peppery enough.  And in the end they charged us for more than we ordered.  We pointed out that we had been overcharged, and they apologized and returned us a bill where we were still overcharged but just slightly less.  It was only a few dollars, so we cut our losses and left...never to return.
author: Jennie L.

description: I'm not a huge fan of India Clay Oven.  The quality of their food seems to vary and isn't consistent.  The wait staff is often bored and unresponsive.  I can't count the number of times I've had to flag someone away from the television to bring me my bill.  For less money I'd rather eat at Naan and Chutney or Naan and Curry.
author: Cyan C.

description: This place had some of the driest chicken tandoori I ever had in my life.
author: Maria M.

description: I ordered take out from here tonite, and the food was flavorless. I had the lamb curry, and it seemed like they forgot to add half the spices. Definitely some of the worst Indian food I"ve had in the city.
author: Srinivas R.

description: This place used to be a well-run establishment, with tasty indian food. We used to frequent the place coz we live within a few blocks, not anymore. Mismanagement and inefficiency seem to have taken over. Last monday, we(party of six) lunched here and it has gone from bad to worse. The lunch buffet used to have plenty vegetarian options, not anymore, just a dal, saag paneer and mixed veg for curries. The saag lacked any salt or oomph, so was the dal and the mixed veg curry. We were not served naan in a quick fashion and had to wave around multiple times to get service. There were only two people serving, the older guy was buried taking phone orders and could not be bothered where as the other one was always inside the kitchen all the time. One of us wanted some pickle and it took them 15-20 mins and multiple reminders to get one, so was additional naan. The worse was the salt lassi we ordered, it was so salty, it was a health hazard. After mentioning this and remaking it, the lassi the second time around was still extremely salty and not possible to be consumed. The lassi was still included in our final bill and we had to point it out to get it removed. All in all mediocre food, sloppy service and indifferent attitude, sad to say but this used to be a good place to get tasty indian food without heading to the southbay or the eastbay. Not anymore.
author: sam j.

description: I introduced my partner  to Indian food here. She was instantly hooked. We ventured to a couple other places since India Clay Oven is on the other side of town but we inevitably made our way back. Love the chicken tikka masala, saag paneer, and cheese naan. Yum. I do have to agree that one of the servers isn't terribly friendly--he has a perpetual look of boredom that grows more pronounced when you try to wave him over.
author: Dora A.

description:
i dunno.

this place looks like its supposed to be a party/club in the evenings with the enormous space in the back. the dining area is well lit, and fancy'ish, but the prices are a bit steep and the portions tiny for most indian/pakistani restaurants. friendly staff though.

if youre really craving indian, go hit Pakwan in the mission. or hell, Great India at Geary/25th ave.
author: Darrell L.

description:
If you haven't sampled Indian food, the lunchtime buffet at Indian Clay Oven from 11:30-2:30pm for only $8.95 is the best way to go! I was quite shocked that the buffet was only $8.95 seeing that the main dishes ranged from $8-11. I took down one star because the food wasn't hot (temperature) because it's been sitting out for too long?, but bonuses for hiring a very courteous and pretty darn' good-looking wait staff, beautiful decor and ambiance (white linens, glasses, and some nice looking silverware I was about to pilfer, Indian art on the walls, great big windows so you can get some Vitamin D while getting additional nourishment while feasting on delicious food). Good place to take a date on during the evenings, or lunch with friends and family (unless your date is into Indian men). There's free validated parking a few blocks away, call to ask.

Included in the package (There were probably around 10-13 food selections with sauces, here are the ones I remember):
Nan Bread (served at the table)
- Mixed rice
- Saag Paneer
- Chicken Tandoori
- Mixed Vegetable Masala
- Kheer (Rice Pudding) 
- Gulab Jamun - Brown cottage ball fried and soaked in a flavored syrup
- Lamb Curry: To die for...mmm
- Fish Pakora
author: May S.

description: This is a great place for Indian from the beautiful, roomy dcor to the excellent food. If you're an Entertainment Book user, you'll find a coupon you can use for BOGO entrees here not once, but many times. The prices of entrees are slightly lower than other places, but the rice and/or naan are not included. We had chicken tikka masala and lamb vindaloo. Both were fantastic. The lamb was perfectly cooked and not chewy. The chicken had a nice, thick sauce with good flavor. It's a little tricky to find parking, but it's worth the hunt for a space.
author: Rachel B.

description: Finally, an Indian buffet with food that is hot! and for only $7.95, such a good deal. Most other Indian buffets leave their food out in pan and it's usually cold by the time i eat it, but this place does a really good job at keeping their food hot and refilling it when running low. has about 10 dishes altogether w/ 2 desert dishes. Scenery beats the hell out of shalimar. It's more americanized - with white napkins for your lap. i do prefer shalimars food better - it just tastes more authentic and is spicier, but for 8 bucks and a nice restaurant i'll definitely go here for my indian food. Buffet ends at 2 just to let you know.
author: Douglas F.

description: This place is wonderful. All of you - go there now - I don't want it to shut it's doors forever just because they aren't busy enough.  As Indian goes, this place is pricey but there is a reason.  Their food is amazingly fresh and every ingredient is identifiable.  No mush and goo here.  Just scrumptious tandoori meats, killer spices, and complex and tantalizing flavors.  The service is impeccable and amazingly attentive.  There is a coupon that comes out in the little blue money mailer coupon envelope that gets you buy one entree get one half off so that is a good way to make it super affordable. They do delivery too but I love going to the restaurant since it is such a nice atmosphere, easy parking, and clean linen tablecloths.  I wouldn't hesitate to take a group here - these guys can accommodate anything.
author: Nadia B.

description: I just loved the way that the sun streamed through their huge glass windows today as I admired the fresh rose on each table. The buffet may be the best indian buffet I have tried. Totally enjoyed the presentation, the linen napkins, and the hot! fresh naan they bring out to every table that is doing the buffet. The service was quiet but on it. So in my head I had us tallied up at about 12.95 a piece for lunch buffet, the upcharge for the ambiance and the details. Nope, 7.95. Delicious chai too.. I can't wait to come back.
author: Jeremi M.

description: 3.5 stars, a bit closer to 3.  Very reasonable and the food is quite good.  The buffet is a very good value. If you crave Indian and are in the area, you shouldn't be disappointed.
author: John W.

description: This place has been our staple Indian takeout / delivery for a few years now.  It's been awhile since I had the $7.95 all you can eat but that's certainly one way to do it!  Over the years I've tried a LOT of things on their menu and can't remember a single time that I was disappointed.  PLUS if you want to be a TOTAL hermit you can now order online: http://indiaclayoven.com/.  Tried it just the other night and it (mostly) worked like a charm.  On the downside, they never called to confirm the order, but on the upside when I called 15 minutes later they said they were already on the way!  So fast!  Always a crowd pleaser around here.
author: Jason M.

description: I would love to write a great review of this place, but I recently ate there and was sick from the food for five days.  Plus the food was kind of pricey for what it was and our bill had all these weird charges on it.
author: Celeste L.

description: This place is awesome. I've been to their San Francisco location three times, and both times, I've had great food, and great service. (I've also been to their San Mateo location a few times, and it's been similarly excellent.) Their Saag Paneer and Lamb Coconut Curry are worth the trip, as are their naans. Their samosas are also pretty good, but I'd say they're fairly average for most Indian restaurants I've been to.
author: Finn G.

description: It gives you a whole lot of food, but I just didn't find it really that flavorful.  It was kinda heavy, but the paneer was good. So, all in all, if you live in the aves and want to walk to some dece indian food, check it out, but it's just mediocre.  But sometimes, you just gotta get some saag, in that case, hit this place up.
author: Ricky R.

description: My husband and I loved! I was never a fan of Indian food but lately I've been craving it. So we went last week. I had Lamb Coconut. Even though the portion looked small at first, it turned out to be enough to take some leftovers home. They offer a delicious Sauvignon Blanc. Order a glass as soon as you sit down - so you can have a second! The service is ON it. It seems like they don't have one waiter per table. Everyone is checking in on you, serving and attending you. We loved our first visit so much that we went back a week later. I had the same dish while my husband ordered the Chicken Masala. We shared among three people - still had leftovers.
author: Kristina T.

description: I really like the food from this place. Very authentic, reasonably priced, and take out is usually very quick.
author: Gary B.

description: Great place for Indian food.  Decor is top notch, price is very decent, and the food is clean and tasty.  Been a fan for many years, and believe it to be a neighborhood jewel.
author: Frank C.

description:
What a terrible place. 

I've been here a couple of times. The time I was there with vegetarians I only noticed the crunchy, matzoh-dry naan and inexplicably slow service (slow even though there were only two other small parties in the restaurant). But this most recent time, the meat was old and nauseating, the naan soggy, and the service rude and even slower. If I could give zero stars I would. 

If you're looking for "sit-down" Indian in the city go to Indian Oven or Gaylord's. If you're not that particular and just want good food go to Shalimar, Pakwan, Naan-n-Curry; any of those hole-in-the-walls will probably have better quality meat.
author: P.J. P.

description:
we came here recently, and i'm still a bit floored as to how much our dinner cost...  we shared:

samosas
sag paneer
plain basmati rice
one garlic naan
one beer
& raita

total: $34

i felt that the amount was a bit steep for an appetizer, beverage, and entree w/2 sides.  considering that it is a nicer indian restaurant, it's still pricey.  i rather make the trek out to the TL and spend a 20-spot w/a load of food.

the service is still on point, but they did not ask me what degree of spiciness i wanted for my dish.  i only came to realize that when i took the first bite and found it to be very mild.  they usually ask how hot you want it.

not sure if i'll be frequenting thins place in the near future.
author: Sheri N.

description:
ok, I gotta say that walking into clay oven's new digs, I felt a bit, well, worried. i mean, a entire indian restaurant where no, repeat _NO_ people of Indian descent were dining

Looking in my whitey McWhiteboy "how to choose an ethnic restaurant without affirmative action" handbook, it says "trust only ethnic restaurants that said ethnicity patronize"...taking a quick spot check, India clay oven gets a negatory on this one...but a tasty multi-multi-course indian meal for 34 buckos thats not naan n curry? sounds pretty promising, and promising it was.

Starting with the super-tasty veggie samosa that was crispy on the outside, moist and flavorful on the inside minus the ridiculous amounts of grease that you usually get with a samosa (which usually pass the Homer simpson napkin "window" test), and moving on to the following courses, it was like a fiesta of flavor.

The next course came with chicken tikka masala (also tasty), some paneer spinachy thing, raita (yum) and best of all, a tandoori mixed grill. Let me say this is hands down, my favorite tandoori plate now in the city. it was good- scary good- like, i'll order 4 more good. The chicken was moist, super-deliciously spiced, and spicy! damn, i'm hungry just thinking about it. 

To top it off, you also get rice pudding- also tasty, but sadly, I was so full, i had to unbutton my shirt just to make enough room...

5 stars for the food/price, -1 for the fact that there was only 1 server for the entire restaurant and the service was understandably slow....
author: Tim V.

description:
I live a few blocks from here so I come for the lunch buffet every now and then on the weekend. For an all-you-can-eat buffet, I think the food is surprisingly good, especially considering the price (around $10 with tax & tip). I also like the restaurant's wall art and their classy linen tablecloths and napkins. The windows are so big that the room is always very sunny and cheerful (at least, when it's not foggy, which in the Richmond is a dicey proposition). You can bring visiting family here and not feel embarrassed, which is not something you can say about many other Indian joints in this city.

I've tried pretty much everything, and the highlights are the chicken tikka masala (they call it something else, can't remember), the tandoori chicken, the lamb curry, and that green mushy stuff that I'm guessing is a mixture of spinach and cheese. I'm also fond of the gulab jamun, the donut-like pastries in the syrup.

As an added bonus, they automatically bring baskets of naan to the table shortly after your arrival, and they'll bring more upon request. It's not the best naan I've ever had, but I think it's very good unless you're unlucky enough to get a burned one.

I've never eaten there for dinner, but looking through the window the ambience seems very nice.

Well worth a visit!
author: Sasquatch M.

description: I dont know why so many reviewers are reviewing and picking on the tiny details of this restaurant. But I was there for the buffet and its all great. Selection was good, and it all tasted great. Setting was good.
author: Monkey C.

description: We stumbled upon this place after hitting the beach this November (yes, it was hot in November!). We intended to eat at the Mediterranean restaurant across the street, but just could not resist an Indian lunch buffet. Their food was good for a buffet. We ate a TON of the chicken makhani, and it was delicious. They don't have as many choices as other buffets, and I didn't like everything I tried. Still, it was an overall great experience and the buffet was still yummy. I don't live near here, but if I did, I would most likely return for that buffet.
author: Bridgette A.

description: Have never been to the restaurant, only delivery. We got our food pretty quickly (30 minutes), but I wasn't very impressed with what we ordered. I had the chicken tikka kabob, which was kinda dry. The spices were so yummy, but I just wish that the chicken had more juicyness to it. Sqeeze alot of lemon, that kinda helps. And the chicken curry, was kinda greasy. The chicken bits they use are good pieces of meat (all white, with no gummy parts). The rice was very dry... and my naan was burned. overall... I'd say it's just average.
author: Marina K.

description:
I was craving Indian for my birthday so a few of my friends and I decided that Indian Clay oven would be a good choice. One of my friends had already been here and said that she thought it was the best Indian food in the city.  I decided to take her advice and try it out.  
 The atmosphere was pleasant with paintings on the wall surrounded by wood inlay.  The tables have linens on them so right away it gives a classy feel to the place.  We ordered two appetizers, the samosas and onion bhaji,which were both very tasty. I decided to order the chicken vindaloos (chicken cooked in hot spicy sauce with potatoes) for my meal which I must say was delicious.  Usually I find Indian food to be really greasy but this time my meal was not (good thing).  Along with every body's meal they gave us about 8 pieces of naan.  The naan was pretty doughy but I'm a big fan of doughy bread so I loved it.  
  The one thing that threw me off guard was how pushy the waiters were.  They kinda just stood there for a while and waited for you to finish something so they could take the plate.  It almost seemed as if they were in a hurry to get us out the door even though there were plenty of tables for customers.  I don't know of I would say this place had the best Indian food but it was really good and it was moderately priced.
author: Julie D.

description: I drive a long way for this Indian food.  The sauces are so rich and buttery - you feel ten pounds heavier after eating it, but it's worth every pound.  Portions are very generous, but it IS a little on the pricey side.
author: Lauren S.

description: the food is tasty, tasty, tasty!!  This was my first Indian restaurant, and I have to admit, I liked it better when it was cheaper and across the street (hence, minus one star).  I remember when the buffet was $7.95, and still am shocked to see that it's more expensive now, especially for someone that can't eat more than 1.5 plates of food.  Alas, times are tough, and the food is definitely worth the price.  if you're a cheap college kid like me, it's better to enjoy this place during the lunch buffet, because they have a lot of their dinner items available, so you can try small samples of lots of dishes without having to pay to order a whole dish and then waste it if you don't like it.  I like that you get naan with the buffet, and even though it may be a dollar more expensive than some other indian food places, i feel the difference in quality and taste is worth it.
author: asia c.

description: It was decent Indian food in a nice atmosphere without an hour and a half wait. The boyfriend's mom was visiting and requested Indian food and I had a hard time trying to find a place nice enough to take a parent too but without the marathon wait that is associated with Dosa. The place is clean and the food is good but not spectacular. They did a good version of the chicken tikka masala. I would skip desserts though. Beware, they do try to upsell you pretty heavily.
author: Cathy T.

description: Okay, good deal, but the leftovers were only okay. Any takeout food should also be tasty the next day. I ended up throwing a lot of it away.
author: Bonnie H.

description: My friends and i were on a search for indian food and we actually drove right up to one on Geary. One quick glance showed that the place was completely deserted so it seemed like a better idea to check out clement street for an alternative. Ergo we found the india clay oven whose general atmosphere radiated warm in contrast to the biting chill outside and thankfully had some customers who appeared to be enjoying themselves.  The food was not particularly special but it was still good. please be forewarned that the cheese is sort of weird. it doesnt really have a taste. but besides that the naan was tasty and our other dishes were good. crazy how multiple dishes add up though. i'm still looking for THE indian place though.
author: Faye P.

description:
my brother and i order delivery here at least twice a week.  in fact, i dont think i've ever actually dined in the restaurant (although i hear it's nice).  it takes at least 50 min to deliver dinner, but it's def worth the wait!

i always ask for their SPICY paneer tikka masala.  yummy!
author: J D.

description: I had my birthday here, and let me tell you, it was an absolutely beautiful setting, with the beautiful murals and giant window panes. The lighting was very romantic as well. The food was pretty good too. this place was all about the frills to me. LOL!
author: Alex Y.

description: The food here is above average and the people who work here are really sweet. I love the saag paneer and chicken tikka. The lunch buffet (which I think is just on the weekends) is a good value and has a good selection of dishes.
author: Carson H.

description: I order vegetarian delivery from this place a lot! I love the Bhindi masalla and recently discovered that if I make a special request they will cut down on the onions! I Almost always order the Chana and a cucumber salad and sometimes I order eggplant as well -and I almost never order bread, rice or appetizers -and I have found that the cucumbers and raita are great for balancing the spiciness without being too heavy. I actually lost weight while relying heavily on this Indian food diet! It tastes wonderful cold for a few days afterward and is a staple in our house now for obvious reasons.
author: Kimberley M.

description: Overall decent food but a little pricey.  I stopped going there when my lamb kebabs were coming out super salty.  The long wait times for delivery don't help either.  The staff are super friendly and it's lovely inside, however, their food has been slipping in the last few months.
author: Bruce B.

description: I always told my friends that Indian food can not go wrong. But finally there it is. It was my first time I order from there. We ordered three dishes from there and all of them taste, shall I say nothing. It seemed like they forgot to add salt and necessary spices. Taste so blend. Their dal soup is like dal and hot water. No exaggeration there. Chicken Biryani, nobody want to finish it and had to throw it away. That's how much we hated it. Their chicken korma is not bad compare to the other two but still with that price I expect the best. So there you have it. I don't think their regular chef prepare for our dishes BUT WE ARE SO DISAPPOINTED! this is not a $7 or $8 dishes. We spent $38 for 3 dishes (including rice). It's not worth it. I am not trying their food again anymore unless someone from their restaurant read my review and try to make it up.
author: Hsan H.

description: I love this place & go often--sometimes just for some mulligatawny soup & pappadum with chutneys & wine, sometimes for the all-you-can-eat buffet lunch & chai, & sometimes with friends so we can share a bunch of different dishes. I love the atmosphere--lots of windows, big murals of idyllic scenes of India on the walls, music, and cute Indian (& other--Nepalese?) guys. Oh, and cloth napkins--the real deal. There are plenty of vegetarian options & even fish dishes, e.g., salmon tikka masala (works really well; who knew?) The host remembers me & always makes me feel appreciated. The buffet is a steal of a deal with so many great yummy delicious & nutritious options--sometimes even carrot halva (a rare treat) & even including salad (if you want your roughage). Meats include a variety of chicken & lamb dishes. (Not sure if they do other meats or shellfish as I'm not into that.) FYI better make the buffet by 2:30-ish, I think.
author: Patricia K.

description: Great grilled food from clay oven. nicely decorated and pretty flatware & silverware.
author: cynthia l.

description: For my money, this is the best Indian restaurant I've found in the Bay area (with the possible exception of Kamal Palace in Berkeley).  The location is a little inconvenient for those who don't often wander out to the further Avenues, but the food is sublime.  They've got the dark, strong mint chutney I love so much (the creamy kind just doesn't really do it for me) and everything I've ever ordered here has just been fantastic--succulent!  Admittedly, I'm a foole for Indian food, but this place is the tops...I must respectfully disagree with Tipsy that India Clay Oven is "just like any other Indian restaurant."  Was 'Trane just like any other saxman?
author: Michael T.

description:
I really like the decoration & feel of the place.  We got take-out so we were just there for a little bit.  We got there early & they weren't ready for us so they sat us down by a window & gave us some water while we waited.  That was nice.  
We took the food home and each took a bite and it was good...for about 15 seconds.  Then the heat hit us.  They ASKED us if we wanted hot, medium or mild, I told them as mild as possible.  What we got was the spiciest food I've ever put in my mouth.  I was STARVING, but I couldn't take more than 3 bites.  My whole head hurt, my stomach hurt, it was miserable.  
I'd love to give this place 5 stars because they were very friendly & it would have been so good if it wasn't so painful.  I'm tempted to try again, but dine-in, so I can send it back if I have to (I've never sent food back before, and do not relish it, but it was called for in this case).  If they can tone it down to our level they will have some very enthusiastic regular customers.
author: Ljótur H.

description: ehh, not bad, not the best, or the closest to me, but hey, they deliver.  They mixed up an entree, and we discovered it after the driver left, and after we'd been waiting for over an hour.  Oh well.  The food was actually pretty decent.  It's good for one leftover meal.  The naan seemed to have been quite a few hours old.  I probablly won't order from here again.
author: Lauren M.

description: Good Food but overpriced......... Good sized portions if you order for pick up
author: spencer k.

description: As a fellow Indian, I would say that the food here is pretty good. The atmosphere is nice, the lunch buffet is definitely reasonable.  By the way, it's not worth going to eat Indian food without the buffet....the variety is what makes the meal!  They just have to watch out and make sure that the bins are always filled otherwise it doesn't look appealing when they are running on empty saag paneer.
author: Bharu J.

description: i've been here on several occasions. the buffet (before 2pm) is totally worth it for under $10. they have a wide selection and it's pretty yummy too.
author: Helen L.

description:
I'll preface by saying that I used to think of myself as not a huge fan of Indian cuisine.  Recently, I've been branching out and have come to enjoy it.  

Went to India Clay Oven last night because of it's proximity to home.  My husband and I ordered the Tandoori meal for two.  What a steal!  For $40 we got apps, grilled meats (lamb and chicken), tikka masala, raita, spinach with cheese, naan.  More food than we could put down, very generous. It was delicious and we couldn't get over the price!

Service was very attentive too.
author: Debbie W.

description: when i get indian i fully intend on being in full sweat mode due to instense spicy foods taking control of me. it's something i love and dread at the same time when considering eating indian. excited and nervous, i ordered the baingan bharta and chicken tikka masala with some rice and naan. after the first bite i was surprised that it all lacked spiciness and for that it gets three stars.
author: Regina C.

description:
THIS IS ONE OF MY FAVORITE PLACES TO EAT IN SAN FRANCISCO!! 

I love this restaurant! Best Indian food in the city. Seriously! 

Chicken Tikka Masala is to die for! Aloo Gobi is so good as well. I can't remember all the names of the dishes I like, but they're all so good. Lots of flavor and tons of care is put into this food! The Masala Chai is also really good. One of the best things to drink here is the Mango Lassi !!! 

The staff is SO SWEET. So kind and generous. It really seems like they love what they're doing. Such nice people. 

Go here for your birthday too, they'll bring you something delicious with a candle on it and sing to you! So sweet.
author: Colleen C.

description: The food always tastes fresh and the sauces are savory.  I love this place.
author: Deb T.

description: Not the best Indian food in the city- average at best. Delivery from here is terrible- we waited 90 minutes for our food and the driver was rude to boot. We had a tandoori mixed grill- the chicken was dry, the lamb was overly spiced and overcooked. Raita wasn't bad.
author: Jay B.

description: Service is impeccable. Food is pretty good but not gourmet, really liked the chicken soup, liked the glass room watching the neighborhood ... food service is pretty quick. We go every once in awhile and like it. The fry bread is yummy, ask for it. You can park right out front in their free reserved spots so that is cool.
author: D R.

description: Been here twice, once for dinner and lunch when they have that buffet special.  Hey you can not beat good Indian food especially that offers buffet for lunch.  India Clay Oven offers different types of masalas, curries and good spinach.  Service was really precise especially when I go for a second plate, they are taking away my first plate once I leave the table and when they see that I'm halfway done with my water, the waiter comes by and fill up my water.  Will go here again during my lunch break for the buffets
author: Kris A.

description: Yummy food, reasonable prices, very attractive decor and table settings, and extremely friendly service! In addition, the portions are very generous for an Indian restaurant, we got our food extremely quickly, and they even brought us a complimentary bread appetizer and dessert. A wonderful experience - we'll certainly be back next time we're craving Indian!
author: Evan and Christine J.

description: I LOVE this place. I order in from here almost every week. At first I was kinda iffy on it because it would take hours for the delivery guy to get here, but I stuck to it, and after becoming a regular customer, delivery time got shaved down to a substantial half an hour. I only give it four stars because the price is a little steep for the amount of food you get, but it really isn't that bad because I order from here so often.
author: Julia B.

description: oh my god... DELICIOUS! i ate enough saag paneer for like 5 people. THE BEST.
author: crystle p.

description: Love the Chicken Tikka Masala (just like they make in my home land - UK :) ) the Garlic Naan and Aloo Gobi - all brilliant!
author: Anna M.

description: I had a pleasant dinner here a few days ago.  The food was consistently good and full of great flavors throughout our meal.  The portions were enough and the food came out fairly quick.  The atmosphere is excellent with white linen and napkins, well lite room, hip Indian beats playing in the background and well groomed staff.  The service is also very outstanding and the prices are reasonable.  Its a great setting for a date.
author: Phat Hippo L.

description: I have been here several times. The Samosas, Palak Pakoras were good. We always order regular Naan. I always order the Chicken Sagg which is pretty good. You can make your curry as spicy as your want, just tell the waiter if they do not ask. When you ask for Spicy, Spicy WOW! it's spicy. We have tired a whole bunch or curry at this place and it's good. Pricey but nice dinning. the staff is nice also. I will keep coming to this restaurant.
author: Ge I.

description: Two words: "Tandoori chicken!" The chicken was tender ,succulent and tasty! Probably my favorite dish at this restaurant. Also, the naan, samosas, rice and chutneys are awesome too! I love the chai tea as well. Ok... maybe... I have a few more favorites other than the chicken! The service was a little inconsistent. But never the less I got a good meal out of it...
author: Suzette R.

description: Overpriced Indian food but I would gladly pay for the cleanliness. I enjoyed the decor and the atmosphere. The food was good. We got Chicken Tikka Masala and Garbanzo Masala. I'm typically not a fan of Indian food, but I enjoyed the Garbanzo dish. Overall, the food was a little on the greasy side and the chicken chunks in the tikka masala were too large and a little tough. The side sauces were very flavorful and not watery like the kind you would get at Naan and Curry. The naan was quite pricey and was decent at best- too dense and heavy. I did enjoy the friendly and attentive staff, as they were helpful and hospitable.
author: Brian H.

description: I love the food here. Awesome. AWESOME!!! The only thing that sucks is that it takes them FOREVER to bring the check out. It's really irritating.
author: Janae L.

description: The lunch buffet here is so YUM!! It's one of the best Indian restaurants in the city!!
author: Kara E.

description: Dont know what the hell I ordered but it was some type of chicken with ginger and garlic in a red sauce....all I can say is it was MMM...Good.  Service was fast all the way around and I enjoyed myself.
author: John D.

description: Bones in the Chicken Makhni. Lots of them. Taste was good, but had to spend a good 15 minutes fishing them out. There were a lot. Nan was doughy and greasy too. And they forgot one of our breads entirely. We were not happy.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
What do you think of when you think of Indian food? I know I think of intense flavor. I like my food spicy, yes, but even without heat, Indian food should be an exciting experience for the tastebuds with a complex layering of spices. This food was just bland. We had the dinner for two, and based on the menu it seemed that we would be getting a great value for all that it came with. But the rice was maybe a bit overcooked and tasteless, the spinach and cheese (why can't i remember the name of that dish?) had no flavor, and the meat was kind of tough. Of the tandoori meats, the lamb was lamby, and the chicken leg that I had was chewy. 
My dessert was fine, the chai tea was fine, and the naan was fine. 
There was something a little weird about all the staff in the restaurant, it felt like people were always looming and hovering around, but that was just because of where they were stationed in the restaurant. Everyone was nice, the waitstaff was attentive, the atmosphere was pleasant. 
I would not go back, though.
author: Megan M.

description: It's always good, whether you go for dinner or the brunch buffet.
author: Andrew S.

description: I've been to many of the Indian restaurants in SF and many in NYC and DC as well, and I highly recommend this place for the freshness of the food, attentive service, high quality preparation, and clean and attractive quality of the decor.  It's really a wonderful restaurant that does a great job with tandooris, curries, nans, dals, biryanis--virtually eveything on the menu was equally delicious.  I noticed that some of the reviews below are not as positive, and most of the less positive ones seem to be about the lunch time buffet.  I can only say that at dinner when we ate there, the food was first-rate in every way, and I'll be back many times!
author: Bob J.

description: I have to agree with Michael about India Clay Oven.  It has been one of my favorite restaurants since I moved to San Francisco.  I was very fond of their previous location, directly across the street from where they are now; the new location is bigger, so it makes sense that they moved there, but I did like the coziness and intimacy of the original place.  However, the food is still just as good, and the people who run it are kind.
author: Sarah G.

description: I love this place!  The service is wonderful, they remember me, and serve chai as I wait for my takeout.  Their food is delicious--the best Indian I've had in the city so far and I love how there's a flower and a candle on every table.  Highly recommended.
author: Caressa M.

description: Great buffet and chai; very attentive service.  The best deal for inexpensive Indian food.  We've been going even before they opened the new location across the street from the old one (at least 8-9 years ago) and still love it.
author: Angelika R.

description: India Clay Oven serves excellent standard Panjabi fare, with constant bhangra in the background for ambiance. The servers, waiters, and greeters are all friendly and helpful. The lunch buffet, in particular, is delicious. And delivery is quick and reliable. What's not to love?!
author: L T.

description:
I just have to say how much I love and miss the awesome Indian cuisine at this restaurant!  I recently moved back to the east coast and cannot find Indian food that tastes as good as it did at India Clay Oven!!

If you go- definitely get the Saag Paneer and the Chicken Korma!!  Soo yummy and not too expensive- definitely a must for richmond foodies!
author: Liz M.

description: In my opinion, this is a fairly good Indian restaurant.  The atmosphere is very nice, the service is quite good and the food is flavorful.  We did have a problem, however, in that my friend ordered her food medium spicy and I ordered mine mild. Once the food arrived and we got into the meal, however, we came to realize that the special requests we each made were obviously mixed up.  I got the spicy version of my entree while my friend got the mild version of hers.  We went ahead and ate them anyway because we were hungry and didn't want to wait for the kitchen to correct the error.  I do have to say the Naan was very good and the Vegetable Samosa was as well.  As for the prices, they are a little steep for Indian food.  Why they--or anybody for that matter--would charge ten bucks for Vegetable Biryani is beyond comprehension. Another thing that bothered me was it felt like the server was encouraging us to over order--after all, two people can only eat so much.  So the bottom line on this restaurant would be it is pretty good but I don't think I would bother going back unless I did so for the lunch buffet and knew they had items on the buffet that weren't super spicy.  From what I hear it is good and I would imagine most of what is on the regular menu is on the lunch buffet for way less dinero.
author: Rabbit B.

description:
7.95 for lunch buffet on a saturday. can't be beat. it wasn't the best indian food i've ever had (possibly because i wasn't too hungry at the time) but even so, i think i've had better. the ambiance is quite nice, even bordering on really fancy. 

it was a little weird however, since upon walking in, there was no hostess or anyone really to tell us what the hell was going on. i had to go up to a waiter to ask if it was lunch buffet. to which he replied, yes. then i asked how much was it? and he looked at me like i was a weirdo and said, "... $7.95" wasn't that a valid question? so we sat down. got our food. we noticed a lack of na'an. and who can realy have Indian food without na'an! so i asked the waiter for an order of na'an. he again looked at me like i was a freak and said, "oh, it comes with the buffet!" ok... that's fine and dandy but how was i supposed to know that considering we sat down about 15 minutes ago?? but it came out super hot and dripping with grease. mmm fresh greasy na'an. overall, i'd have to say i'd definitely go there again. since i'll know what the deal is next time and i won't have to ask "stupid"questions!
author: Karva S.

description: Open late, delicious food, totally affordable (esp vegetarian dishes), filling, great service, fancy lookin', and I'm going back!!
author: D L.

description: Adequate $7.95 lunch buffet but very uninspiring.  Excellent lamb curry.  Chicken Makhni and Saag Paneer were both too heavy on the butter/cream.  The fritters are good, but they should get rid of the fried fish and put something better there.  First place that I liked the Gulab Jamun.  Also first place that really messed up on the Kheer - not nearly sweet enough and too heavy on the cream too!  The only thing going for the place is that it's really pretty inside!  Two walls of windows.  So it's good to take people here who don't know Indian food.  Just make sure to sit with your back to the front windows because you don't need mediocre indian food and have the sun in your eyes too.
author: A P.

description: Incredible! The $10 all you can eat buffet is an insane deal and is so good. The service is impeccable, the dishes fresh, and the naan plentiful. If you can make it to the buffet, you won't be sorry!
author: Kristen R.

description: This restaurant is definitely a favorite of mine.  So far all the different dishes tried have been delicious.  I really enjoyed the curry with apricots and their garlic naan is always perfect.  The spiced tea is a real treat.  Overall coupled with tasty dishes with the warm nicely dressed ambiance, friendly and polite staff, it's worth a visit.
author: Mara O.

description: Awesome place for brunch with great service, can't say enough good things
author: Raman R.

description: went here for dinner the other night and came to the conclusion that the lunch buffet is what completely makes this place. it's too expensive otherwise.
author: Allie M.

description: The decor is nice and the restaurant is clean.  But that's the best of it.  You can get much better food at chains like Naan 'n Curry for 1/2 the price.  Also, sometimes it's not clear what the meat is in the curry.
author: C.S. K.

description: Just got back from there. The best thing about this place is the high ceilinged room.  Went there for lunch buffet and I am still hungry and disappointed.  The buffet's food was just bad, plus, there was no dal. Better to go to Great India on Geary where the food is delicious and the dal exists.
author: leigh m.

description: Ok, so I know that this is not the best opener for my review debut.  I have eaten at his buffet around 5-6 times in the past 10 years, and I really believe that they put a filler like baking soda or something that fills you up faster so that you eat less.  I know this because I never feel like this after going to places like Shalimar or Naan N Chutney, and I don't have that food hungover constipated feeling for the next two days.  Sorry folks, but it may taste good, but if it doesn't make you feel good, then it's not fresh or clean food.  I was there the other day and 4 out of 5 people eating with us expressed the same feeling.  Ok, Clay Oven, you may be saving pennies to have people eat less, but do you want to be remembered as the restaurant that the CEO's of Rolaids live and die for?  The new location is much better that the old one across the street...much more light and space.   Take along your acidopolis or antacids along.
author: Jessi B.

description: buffet, buffet, buffet. soooo good. if you want a pretty inexpensive lunch that is ridiculously tasty, be sure to hit up india clay oven. i'm a huge fan of the selection, and the staff is really nice. dinner is great, too. you cannot go wrong with this creamy, cheesy chicken dish (forgot the name). the waiters will know what you want. enjoy!
author: Aly L.

description: i used to like this place like 6 or so years ago.  food was decent, the service was awesome, and the mango lhasi was noteable.  however, the last two times that i visited this place, i got "food poisoning" in the worst way.  i don't even know why they call it food poisoning.  that term sounds way too nice for what happened to me.  it was more like ass vomit.  the only reason that i give them two stars is because the service was great, even though the food should be classified as a WMD.
author: Lex E.

description: I thought the portions were small and was unimpressed by teh food.  The samosas were great but everything else seemed bland and like a small portion to me.  I'm surprised that other people like it so much.  It's nice inside, but I'm really racking my brain to come up w/ stars here...
author: Rainforest C.

description: great food and service, but how was the nan so subpar? it was flat and hard and would not soak up any of the tasty sauces.
author: Mr G.

description: I like this place ok.  Again it is ok for a local joint and for a craving.  I won't seek it out otherwise but if you are in the mood and don't have high expectations then you got it!
author: Misti L.

description: We went here one night for dinner just by accident (since we are tired of the restaurants on Clement St - 2nd to 12th)...and we came across this restaurant. I thought it was nice and fancy. The CS was satisfactory and the food was great. I'm a fan of the garlic naan and curry so I ordered those. The food was superb and nothing like those other Indian restaurants I've been too in the city. If you want authentic Indian food, go to this place.
author: JM M.

description: whenever i am too tired to cook for me and mine, i get the clay oven dinner for 2 and substitute the vegetable of the day with the aloo matter.  it's always satisfying and delicious!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Elegant, airy room, and nice comfortable setting, a plus. Attentative, friendly service, table cloth, linens, and settings a plus. Bhaingan Bartha, spicy whipped eggplant dish, mixed into aromatic rice, to die for.  Chicken tikka masala, lovely sauce, rubbery textured chicken.  Delicious mango lassi, the best in the city, more fresh mango flavor than any where else. Pistachio Kulfi, Indian ice cream, yum, cardamom!
author: Tara W.

description: they moved across the street. i guess they took the decor of what used to be a japanese restaurant that never really worked out..sad to say. atmosphere is nice with funky indian music. if it's your birthday, you'll get a pretty cool drum solo along with the jingle. the food's pretty good. just like any other indian restaurant, but with nice big windows.
author: Connie L.

description: When this place was at it's old location (across the street), I wasn't very impressed by the food, but luckily I decided to try it in it's new space. The dining area is upkept and relatively quiet. I usually end up spending more money than I intend because everything sounds so delicious, and because of this I have to eat here sparingly. I have heard a couple people getting sick after eating here, but since I haven't gotten it myself yet, I gave it 5 stars. haha
author: Tami H.

description: Just like everyone else said, the lunch buffet was excellent, as was the service.  It was definitely worth the price.  I only wish they had chai tea, the perfect end to an extremely large Indian meal.
author: Jeff B.

description: Perhaps the best Indian food we ever had in the city.  The people who owned the place were very nice, which more than made up for the slightly slow service.  Everything was excellent, from the naan through the main course (including a veggie masala and another chicken dish that was very spicy) and desert.  We thought it was a great find.
author: Larry M.

description: The wait staff was really friendly and attentive.  I dropped my knife on the ground, and a nanosecond later, the waiter gave me a new knife.  The naan was great and many to choose from. The cheese naan, however, was so so...couldn't even tell there was cheese in it.  The meat platter appetizer was dry.  The lamb was so dry and over cooked it was hard to even cut it with my knife.  Everything else seemed ok and expensive.
author: LT B.

description: I've been in desperate search for good Indian delivery.  Was very disapointed with India Clay Oven.  The Saag Chicken had nice flavor.  However, the other curries were just ok and the nan was very doughy.  We're probably spoiled with Shalimar which is great, inexpensive food if you want to do take out.
author: Kari G.

description: when it comes to Indian cuisine, ghee is used in everything or not at all. it really depends on the restaurant. i like it when the food tends to not be heavy. so from my experience i think Clay Oven might not use ghee. i can eat a lot and not feel tired afterwards. the restaurant is beautiful inside and their delivery service is fairly quick. obviously plenty of vegetarian options.
author: Daniel N.

description:
I've been going to this place for 10 years now, and I keep coming back.  It used to be a small place, but moved across the street a few years ago and is bigger, cleaner, and brighter inside.  The ambience change is like night and day.  Service has improved dramatically over the past year.  I boycotted this place for a year b/c the old servers snickered when my sister asked for a new cup (old one had a lipstick stain on it).  When I ventured back, they had all new servers and they are very courteous and hospitable
   The food is awesome.  In my opinion I haven't had na'an better anywhere (e.g. Na'an and Curry, Shalimar)  It is always served hot out of the oven - oh so soft, moist and chewy on the inside and a little crispness on the outside.  The curries, overall, are excellent, very bold, but never overpowering or bland.  The only curries I don't like here are the vindaloo and the saag.  Biryani, my favorite dish, is not this place's strong suit, too wet and too mild.  
   The out-of-this-world na'an, improved service and ambience takes this to a 4 star in my book

Food: 4 stars
Ambience: 4 stars
Service: 4 stars
Value: 4 stars

Overall Rating: 4 stars
author: Michael L.

description: Nice place... And that's where it ends.  I heard this place was really good.  So I said "OK, let's go" cuz I like Indian food.  We basically found the food was good, but not great... service was ok and overpriced.  I've had better Indian food at a buffet.  I'm a big fan of "good and cheap".  This place is not.  Enough said.
author: gummy j.

description: Ordered the food for delivery. It came late, and was not that good at all. I am dissapointed. What a waste of my money!
author: Heidi N.

description: Pretty bland Indian food.  The naan was chewy and they seem to lean on onion with almost every dish.   This place is priced like the better Indian spots around town, but the food is at the bottom of my list regardless of price.
author: Andy B.

description: I have this place deliver to my house at lease once a month.  I can't get their Punjabi spiced chicken out of my mind.  If you have them deliver be sure to allow yourself an hour wait until they make it but it's much worth the wait.  The staff is nice and they serve your food in the cutes bowls. I haven't found anywhere else as good as this.  I still haven't had the pleasure of going to their lunch buffet but I will soon
author: lup b.

description: We are new to living in this part of the city and wanted to try a new Indian. We were not disappointed. The chicken curry punjabi was spicy and engaging, the vegetable samosas crisp but not greasy, and the eggplant was indeed as advertised by others on this list.  The environment is good, the waiters kind and attentive, and the prices reasonable. We will be back.
author: Andrew M.

description: I love the decor here; the nice white tablecloths, medium lighting, and individual roses on the tables make this a very nice date restaurant.  Plus the food is good!  I'm not a huge fan of very spicy food, and I found the dishes at India Clay Oven to be a good compromise.  There was a lot of flavor without a lot of mouth-burning agony.
author: Corinna R.

description: ill keep it simple... the chicken tikka masala is sooo good! and the service is good.
author: paola b.
